Doc ID: 12089, distribution: 0.31025642687803834 ; mirithebrave:  
 “similarly to not blaming folks for where they are when a system placed them there, we can use a strengths-based approach with people in our lives. relaxing isn't always possible. same with letting go. so instead of telling people to “just relax” or “just let go” we can gently wonder, and even ask: what about this is scary or challenging? can i see the wisdom in the not-relaxing, in the tight holding? ⊹ this wondering can help us see where another person is, why they are there (even if it's just: oh they don't feel safe to relax. they can't “just let go.” i now see it's not that simple), the strength in their choices (as well as the choiceless choices. see: yesterday's post), and supports they might need. ⊹ there is so much i could say about this, and i will. ⊹ like how: there is often deep wisdom and strength in the ways we cope, even while the ways we cope can feel disruptive to our lives. ⊹ like how: this relates to bodywork and touchbased modalities, and how practitioners can honor the tightness, the holding and muscle guarding as protective not defective.”

Doc ID: 2531, distribution: 0.8638660853172053 ; A very Merry Christmas photo dump 🎄 because life is too short to spend another Christmas at war with yourself 🥲

These photos remind me of how many incredible moments you can create with the people you love when you're no longer putting such an unnecessary pressure on yourself, when you're not avoiding the feasts or turning down the photos or allowing the feelings of guilt to overwhelm you.

I'll be honest, I still experience some subconscious feelings of guilt after overeating every now & then, it's something I've experienced from a young age but those feelings have definitely lessened over the past few years since I've started focusing on the way my body FEELS (my overall health & happiness) rather than the way my body LOOKS. I know deep-down that I have nothing to feel guilty about, so I've been ignoring those subconscious feelings of guilt, pushing past them, being gentler with myself & enjoying lots of incredible food anyway!!! WE'VE GOT THIS 💪🏼

So this post is for you, but also for me, to remind you to be gentler to yourself today (& every day). If you've eaten a lot today & you're starting to be unkind to yourself, I just wanted to remind you that you deserve food. You deserve to enjoy feasting on Christmas Day. You deserve to be present. Your body won't transform overnight & even if it did (which it won't) that's okay!!! There's nothing wrong with that. You DON'T deserve to be hard on yourself. Enjoy today, if you can. And if nothing else today makes you smile, I hope this will….

I love you. Merry Christmas 🎄💛

#merrychristmas #photodump #christmas #happyholidays #bekindtoyourself

Doc ID: 9747, distribution: 0.556897078107438 ; i feel like the concept of mindfulness has a stigma of being a bit “woo woo” if you know what i mean.  when i used to think of mindfulness, i solely thought of things such as meditation and yoga, eating slowly and in silence, and being environmentally sustainable. now, i realize that although living mindfully can include those things, it doesn't always have to and is also so much more.

living mindfully to me means living with intention whatever that means for you. it's not an all or nothing thing, and mindful living, just like healthy living, looks different person to person because it's about knowing your own personal why and keeping it in mind when making decisions.

for me, mindfulness includes:
pausing and thinking before reacting,
eating things I actually want to eat,
taking time to slow down,
doing things for my community,
moving my body from a place of gratitude,
seeking out things that make me feel fulfilled,
and showing compassion.

my intentions? to be happy, live freely, and have an impact.

side note: the typical summer cravings are in full swing over here (hi smoothies, salad, ice cream, and popsicles!), so i'm extra excited for the next time i can get my hands on a @pressedjuicery freeze :)

Doc ID: 9540, distribution: 0.34791117584870557 ; “shared joy is a double joy; shared sorrow is half a sorrow.”

i'm still a work in progress with being open about my pain and reaching out for help, but i'm so grateful for the people in my corner who have been there for me when it's hard for me to be there for myself.

just a reminder that
it's not weak to reach out for help,
vulnerability is a strength,
mental illness is real,
mental health is important,
and checking in with people can make the biggest difference.

we are all going through things we don't talk about 🤍

.

.
.

.

Doc ID: 8109, distribution: 0.6550528514210976 ; sleep.
.
it's been an enemy of mine for some time now. you would think working full time with a  hour round trip commute every day would make hitting the pillow extremely easy. i wish! even if i'm terribly exhausted, falling and staying asleep are struggles for me. im constantly looking for new ways to enhance my abilities to fall asleep as well as the quality of my sleep. 
so when i came across an article that my friends over at @thethirty put together on a sleep trick, i was intriguing. and desperate. .
have you heard of the // trick? i hadn't until i read about it. the article explains it best, but essentially this is a breathing trick that forces your heart rate down. doing so allows your body to prepare for sleep. you take  seconds to inhale a deep, deep breath. then you hold that breath for  slow seconds. finally you release the breath slowly, using  full counts. the first time i tried this, on around  or  seconds of the exhale, i literally felt my muscles loosen. the fist i was unaware i was holding under my pillow actually released itself. i felt like i melted into my sheets. .
and hours later...i woke up.
i had fallen asleep within minutes. and i didn't wake up countless times during the night. i realize this sounds absurd. magical even. .
but simply forcing my body to prepare for rest was all i needed to do to cross the bridge into sleep. i'll be completely honest and say this works  times out of . there are still nights where i'm restless and lose plenty of sleep. but i wanted to share this trick with you all because it has helped me immensely! .
i also find a five minute deep stretch before bed to help me get into a state that's prepared for sleep. on days where i cant tackle my racing mind i rub lavender oil on my chest and wrists and have found success with that as well!
.
what are your bedtime tips and tricks for falling asleep? i'd love to hear them! .
.
.
.
.

#sleep #healthy #foodie #foodblogger #sleeptricks #bettersleep #decor #urbanoutfitters #bedroominspo #anthropolgie #roominspo #bedroom #plantbasedblogger #wellness #healthyinspo #healthylife

Doc ID: 2383, distribution: 0.8911437831423723 ; The beach used to be one of my least favourite places... I felt like I couldn't eat beforehand or else I'd bloat, so I'd be sitting in a baggy t-shirt, under the sun, starving and comparing myself to all the girls beaming with confidence, feeling terrible!!! 

And now? Sunny days + the beach + @yoproau's new frozen dessert tubs + a great book + feeling comfortable with my bloated wobbly self in bikinis = the ideal date!! AD

I now have room in my mind & heart to no longer feel like I'm in competition with the people around me, but rather cheer them on & feel proud that they are comfortable in their skin too.

When you're struggling with something within yourself, it clouds your thoughts & perspective towards everything else in your life. I truly believe working on yourself will always be an amazing investment of your time!!

Being able to enjoy an ice cream at the beach on a hot summer's day was something I deprived myself of so many times, but I am so happy to no longer let my inner critic take control... It's okay to enjoy food without guilt, it's okay for your body to change across the day (and your lifetime) & it's okay to listen to your cravings.

For me, listening to my body means embracing that I have a massive sweet-tooth, but that my skin breaks out & my gut doesn't love when I consume TOO much sugar... So I like to live my best Hannah Montana life & live the best of both worlds by sometimes opting for a more balanced, nutritious choice! That's why I dropped into Coles to grab a tub of @yoproau's new Frozen Desserts = Salted Caramel Peanut & Double Choc ice creams, with g of protein per serve & no added sugar! 🍦

Doc ID: 9763, distribution: 0.378227357649631 ; i woke up pretty bloated this morning, so my game plan to tackle the bloat is:

to do absolutely nothing different.

i'm not a health professional, so i'm not qualified to dish out any sort of medical advice, but what i do know about bloating is that for the general population, it is very normal, it can be caused and exacerbated by a lot of different factors (including stressing about it), and it does not affect who you are or your worth.

i'm bloated, and i'm not going to dissect my body, restrict my food, or force myself to move my body. those are not options for me anymore. instead, i'm going to continue to accept my body, listen to my body, honor my body, and eat a slice (or however many i feel like) of this raw vegan snickers pie from my super talented friend @annaintheraw (which you can find at her cafe @annaintherawcafe in downtown cleveland) ✌🏽

Doc ID: 2709, distribution: 0.5355373398108897 ; WHEN YOU'RE OLDER, WILL IT MATTER? 🤔

These are some of the classic self-sabotage thoughts I had up until this year. At the beginning of  I started asking myself, “Will it matter when I'm older?” and it really helped me to stop overanalysing the small stuff and missing out on things that would bring me JOY.

When you're , will you really be wishing you never ate that block of chocolate? Or will you be more upset that you turned down a night with your friends because you were on a diet? 

Life will pass us by... So wear that bikini to the beach, upload that photo, go on that date, start your journey to health, spend a whole day watching movies, take a risk, skip leg day if you're not feeling up to it... Life is precious & can be challenging enough without the extra pressure we constantly put on ourselves. 

Please, do yourself a favour, next time you stop yourself from doing something you'd find enjoyment from, ask yourself “When I'm older, will it matter?” 👵🏼 

Hit share if you think someone who follows you needs to see this 💛

Btw, say hi to my grandma 🥰 isn't she the sweetest?

Doc ID: 9744, distribution: 0.6610724825286749 ; opposite action is something that when i committed to recovery and trying to rewire my brain, REALLY helped me combat my negative thoughts and stop labeling my actions.

essentially, opposite action means deliberately doing the opposite of your harmful emotional urge.

if i had the urge to run, i would choose to get closer.

if i had the urge to isolate myself, i would choose to reach out to someone.

if i had a thought telling me that i “shouldn't” eat the chocolate cupcake, even if i didn't know if i really wanted to eat it, i would choose to eat the cupcake anyway with the goal of taking away the power from the food and transferring the power back to myself by making the decision.

this helped me eventually change the thought process from thinking i “should” or “shouldn't” do something to thinking about if i do or don't WANT to do something.

initially, opposite action can feel really scary because it's literally going completely against what your thoughts want, but that's why it works. the more and more you do things that feel scary, the less scary they become, and the more you're able to actually tune into how you really feel and make the choice you really want. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 9123, distribution: 0.8603040400678217 ; you don't need as much protein as you think... or maybe you need more protein than you think? what's the real answer?

well, the real answer is that no, you don't need to track anything in particular to be healthy. what you do need to do is pay attention to how you feel, and what your goals are. if your goal IS to build muscle, technically more protein is good but there's a good change you're getting what you need and you're not working out in the way that promotes muscle growth. if you don't add in protein rich foods to your meals and you feel hungry two hours after a big smoothie bowl with just fruit, you might need to add some protein. if that doesn't bother you and you'll just eat again, then honor you should that.

then there's the whole camp of people who say you shouldn't even think about protein when eating. I think there's pros and cons to this. if you're eating a diet that is colorful, has a high variety and foods from all food groups (grains/legumes included) and you feel energized, chances are you're getting what you need. 
personally i like to add supplements because I LOVE smoothie bowls but I got stuff to do so I like it to be satisfying for the next couple hours. I do love it for the taste also (salted caramel maca whaaaat). I also add other things that make a meal satisfying— nut butters, granola, seeds, nuts, etc. ive been using a lot of @vivolife lately and i'm really liking it! it's an all vegan brand / company, products are carbon neutral, and they're going in the zero waste direction! use my code AMANDA at checkout to save you $$$

But now, when someone mentions calories, I just get pissed off at THEM instead. Im no longer angry at myself for being like everyone else, with a functioning human body. Im angry at them for trying to make me feel like shit for being a fucking human. No one gives a shit if you ate healthy. No one gives a shit if you ate junk food. We are all gonna die. Why bother counting calories. Why would i want to spend my life doing sad MATH of all things

🍑 Curves
🤪 My personality… I feel like I'm more me, which makes me more fun to be around!
💖 Love… I have even more love to give now. Who would've thought that once you've learned how to treat yourself with love, you would have more to offer the world in return!! 
👯‍♀️ A desire to go out, eat out, make friends, say yes more & have fun!
⏰ TIME… I gained so much time back that I used to spend: thinking about food, tracking and weighing my ingredients, searching menus before going out, working out for longer than necessary, researching weight management, etc. I now have so much more room in my mind to think about things that really matter.

No matter how lean I was, I still wasn't good enough… I still wanted to lose more, or gain muscle, or change something… But now I understand it never had anything to do with the way I looked to start off with. What it really came down to was my mentality… Instead, I should've focused on how I spoke to myself, my mental & physical health, my happiness, and how much more I had to offer than my physical appearance. 

So I did. But I would've missed out on all of that if I continued to put the way I looked before the way I felt.

This isn't to villainise a leaner body type — I am still in a thin body, I won't deny that — this is about how I TREATED my body & all of the things I turned down in order to look a specific way. I hope this will encourage you to live a fuller life. Including your tummy! 🥰 This body I'm in now fluctuates throughout the year, it's the body that allows me to live my life focused on the things that really matter to me and make me happy. You deserve a life full of the same!! 💐

#weightgain #weightgainjourney #foodfreedom #balanceiskey #thenandnow #surplus #fitnessjourney #healthjourney #recoveryispossible #recovery #encouragement

Doc ID: 2592, distribution: 0.36040452629259223 ; Strong VS still strong!💪🏼 If the way you feel about your body is holding you back from going out with friends, joining a gym & just living the happy, healthy, FREE life you want to lead, then the issue isn't your body, it's your mindset / inner critic.

“Too big, too skinny, too short, too tall, too outspoken, too quiet, trying too hard” — there's this feeling that we're all 'too' something while at the same time not good enough.

And it's crippling. But guess what? Telling your brain all of these things is only adding fuel to the fire. If you're filling your mind with these thoughts, it's no wonder it's all you see when you take a glance at your own reflection. As I've mentioned before, your brain looks for all the things you've told it in order to confirm & validate how you're feeling. So when you start speaking positively to yourself, slowly in time, that's what you'll start to seek & find.

So I'm just leaving this series of posed VS unposed photos here each Monday to remind you not to compare YOUR real to someone else's Instagram highlight reel. A lot of what you see online is the photos on the left, but what I see is the version on the right because that's what my body looks like % of the time when I relax & just let my body be free. I used to struggle to even look at the unposed, unedited, natural, normal version of me… But now I appreciate & embrace all versions of me. THAT'S the version of yourself that you deserve to feel comfortable in too.

You can either view yourself through a negative lens or consciously start choosing to view yourself through a positive one — easier said than done, of course — but which lens are you going to start choosing? Let me know in the comments for accountability!!! Leave a “➖” for negative & a “➕” for positive! Put it out there 🙌🏼

Happy Real Me Monday angels 👼🤍🌱 have the best possible week & don't forget to be kind to your mind! Chat to you in the comments ✨

#unedited #positivethinking #nocomparison #confidence #femalepower #feelinggood #beyourownkindofbeautiful #beautiful #happyinmyskin #flawsandall

Doc ID: 14914, distribution: 0.3155161804502401 ; Question: Hi Faith :)) What was the environment around food like for you growing up? Answer: Ugh it was awful. Almost every negative thing you can think of related to food went on in my house. My mum dieted, she tried to get my dad on a diet - endless different diets. There was shaming around weight. Fat shaming. Good food and bad food. Lots of talk over numbers of calories and fat in food. Guilt over being hungry and being told “oh you can't possibly be hungry”. Commenting on what people were eating. Mealtimes were stressful, a place where we were always told off for table manners, high anxiety, often ending in shouting (my dad) and crying (my sister and I). My dad did a lot of secret eating and my mum had tight control of the kitchen and knew what food had gone. She hid food to stop it being eaten. We had to ask permission before we could get anything to eat. Sometimes if my mum was away for the day, I was left in charge of making sure my dad didn't eat any bad things. My dad was delighted at being left on his own and would take us out for lunch and eat very indulgently, leaving me caught in between my parents actions. If we went out for a family meal, my dad would eat too much and my mum would look in great pain having to watch him, she would be wincing and pulling faces and commenting.Looking back on it all in therapy, it is of absolutely no surprise that controlling my eating became the coping mechanism I ended up using to manage my feelings. Eating was connected with such high anxiety and so polarised already that it was only a small step to falling into unhealthy behaviours. The one positive is that it has made me absolutely % clear on what NOT to do with my own children.

I feel like I need you to be there with me.” I know we are coming to the end of the session and I'm about to be on my own for three weeks. “Would it help if you knew you could message me if you needed to?” I nodded. T turned the conversation to lighter things and I suddenly came up with a rush of things to tell her. know that your worth does not lie in how you look,

and STILL want to lose weight.

Doc ID: 2561, distribution: 0.5691577775688781 ; The words “I am” are powerful, because whatever you follow it up with has the power to make or break you.

Your body hears it. Your mind hears it. You feel it.

As an experiment, I stood in front of the mirror after a shower, looked at myself & said “I'm ugly” — I instantly felt sad & it became so much easier to start picking out the things I didn't love. The negative thoughts were almost instantaneous.

But then I closed my eyes, refreshed my mind, opened my eyes again & said “I'm beautiful” — that instantly felt better. I instantly felt kinder towards myself. I noticed I started to smile at my reflection.

I know it won't be as easy as that for everyone, so please don't feel like a failure if you can't bring yourself to be kind BUT please try to remember that when you speak about yourself throughout the day (every day), your mind & body takes that in. It starts to become part of your identity. And not only does your body take those comments in, your friends, your family, your colleagues, your audience online does too.

My future children will never hear me say:
I'm ugly
I “can't” wear that
Gross, look at my…
I'll have to work that off in the gym
I can't, I'm trying to be “good”
When I lose weight…
I look gross

Things my children WILL hear me say:
Yum, that was delicious. I enjoyed every bite!
I'm so proud of myself
I am worthy of that
I feel beautiful in this
I'm a good person 
I feel great today!!

Moral of the story & challenge of the week: let's try to be mindful of the thoughts we tell ourselves & the comments we make about ourselves. It's okay to have a bad body image day, I'd never tell you to internalise your feelings, but try to acknowledge when those thoughts are happening & get into the habit of rephrasing them or doing your best to be kinder to yourself. If you're gonna try it this week, leave a “🙏🏼” in the comments for accountability! You've got this 💗

Happy Real Me Monday!! Your body is worthy of embrace ALWAYS. Don't forget that when you're scrolling through social media today! xox

Wearing Gymshark - link in bio 🛍

#comparison #dontcompare #igvsreality #expectationvsreality #sidebyside #womenshealth #realness #selflove

Doc ID: 7584, distribution: 0.8580851632227755 ; this morning i received a dm in which a user was quite frustrated with me and my content. they argued that the lifestyle i portray is very triggering and curated because it only focuses on “healthy” (used in quotes because the term is wildly subjective) eating and fails to show “the more real, unhealthier aspects” of my life.
.
.
phew, let me sit down for a second.
.
.
i'll begin with this bold, blunt, and blatantly truthful statement: i'm not obligated to prove anything to anyone. i dont express this from a place of defense or anger, but rather one of sadness, feeling misunderstood. everything i'm about to say is not fueled by hate but rather a cathartic release of emotions that this message raised.
.
.
i live a full life beyond the confines of a photo grid on a social media platform. i shouldn't be expected to capture every single second and showcase them all. it's unrealistic. obsessive. for lack of a better word, “unhealthy”.
.
.
to address how my feed is too “healthy”: my account is a creative outlet for me to explore a deep passion of mine, health and wellness. i thoroughly enjoy cooking with nutrient dense, wholesome ingredients. this is my lifestyle. i've earned the right to practice it in every way.
.
.
when i eat what this user is referring to as “unhealthy” foods, i'm likely surrounded by friends and family at the time. i'm living in the moment, being present and making memories, not capturing photos and using their company to curate content. when i'm drunk eating pizza with my friends at  AM or stuffing my face with my mom's famous cookies, i'm not capturing a perfectly curated shot to place on my feed. i'm…busy…living.
.
.
just because you don't SEE these things doesn't mean they don't happen. could i make more of an effort to showcase them? sure, but the purpose of this account is to serve my wellbeing. always be wary of comparing your life to ones you see online. nobody is telling the full picture, and you can't expect them to do so in order to placate you. i do my best to communicate balance through this platform. i hope that is enough.
.
.
if it is not, so it goes. i wish you the best! rest assured, i'm *certainly* living my best life ♥️

Doc ID: 8873, distribution: 0.6583953847834318 ; advice/tips on handling being down/overwhlemed from the pandemic?

this was something a story-watcher asked me to talk about this week

to be honest with you, i don't have a SOLID answer for you. this is mostly because i don't know what you've gone through and i don't know how your mind works exactly

but here are a few things i would like to share with anyone feeling down or overwhelmed by all of this: 

you are OKAY and it is OKAY

you didn't get into that workout routine you thought you'd get into this summer? that's OKAY

you didn't get the grade you thought you would get on the online class you took? you had to withdraw because taking classes online for the past  months hasn't been easy? that's OKAY

you feel anxious/nervous thinking about going outside and getting back into a social scene? that's OKAY

you feel side tracked with your goals and unsure of life? that's OKAY

i don't know what you are going through right now, but i can tell you that what you went/are going through was/is not easy. and it's important to give yourself grace when you need to, as well as tough love when it feels right

i hope that i can remind you that it's OKAY to take your time getting comfortable with whatever you set out to do. it's OKAY to keep saying no until you feel ready to say yes. 

of course, there is a line between being complacent and being protective of your energy/health. when making a decision, try to be honest with yourself and ask yourself what ~feels~ right to you. you'll often be led to the best answer.

the BEST thing you can do for others in this world is to work on yourself. this includes being patient, loving, and protective towards yourself as well. if i don't cleanse and love that space within me, how can i possibly provide a safe space for others? care for others, but remember you are a human who deserves that care too.

last but not least, you're not alone. you matter. you are important. you deserve to be here and as happy as all the people you love in your life. 

that is all. thanks for reading the (mostly unrelated) caption under this picture of me and @kiaralovepup 🥰

Doc ID: 17033, distribution: 0.8737854635420123 ; Question: My boyfriend and I have been together for  years and living together for most of that. We're not married but it's definitely on the cards in the not so far future. The thing is that he earns double what I do (k) but we pay exactly half of every outgoing each. He knows how much (how little) I earn and I just feel like although it's equal, it's unfair proportionally and I'm not sure how to broach the topic and I don't know if I should's so many different approaches, and different things work for different couples. H and I just have one joint account, all our money goes into it and all our outgoings come out of it and all the money belongs to both of us. That works great for us. But I know other couples do different things that work great for them. There's not one right answer.So yes, you should definitely definitely talk about it with your boyfriend. At some point you must have had a conversation that resulted in your current set up. But how is it going to work if one of you loses your job, or has to stop work because of illness, or you have a baby and one of you takes parental leave and isn't earning? It is totally within your right to ask your partner to have a conversation about it. What's more it's healthy and a sign of a strong relationship if you can talk about these important things and think about how you would cope with various potential events in the future. You don't have to come up with the solution in the first conversation, and it's probably best if you don't approach it with a “the current set up isn't fair” (even if you don't think it is!) But just open the conversation and start thinking about your options and make space for both of you to share how you feel about things. How have you both formed your views on money? How did each of your parents handle money? Did you have plenty of money in your childhood or was money tight? Do you have any big savings goals? How much debt do you both have, and how is it being paid off? How do you feel about credit cards? loans? a mortgage? Are you spenders or savers? Do you give to charity?Now go, talk about it!!

Doc ID: 16085, distribution: 0.6480315759334571 ; Question: I've been having a really hard time lately fighting with the majority of my friends. We are constantly arguing about how much they are struggling "adulting" and managing their money. Most of them just started living on their own, when I have been for yrs, and all make more money and have lower bills but all constantly have to get help or have like $ to their name. It's getting to the point I don't want to talk to them anymore because it's so frustrating. Help tumblr mom!  Answer: Ah that's tough anon, you are in a different life space to your friends. Living independently is a big shock and there's lots to get used to, and you do feel like you've got too much to do and no money, plus having to do all those boring routine adulting things. Living on your own for six years, you are several steps ahead of them in independence and experience. Stuff your friends are struggling with will probably have become things you can do without thinking now, and then it can be difficult to remember how much energy just basic living took up when you started out.Only you can decide whether your friendships can get through this. Can you spend time together without talking about money or adulting? You don't need to fix all their situations. Or maybe you need to try and meet new friends that fit more with the phase of life you're in. Friendships often do move around as we move through different stages of life, we drift apart from some friends and become closer to others. Some friendships survive the varying stages of life, by focusing on what they have in common or being willing to listen to each other's struggles even if we can't really appreciate the situation the other one is in.You probably can't change your friends or their struggles, so the ball is in your court. If it really feels too frustrating to keep seeing them, then you can gently pull away - maybe even only temporarily. If you do keep seeing them, then I think you just have to find a way to accept that these are their struggles right now and they're valid, just as your struggles in the place you're in are also valid. Some people feel they're the worst off, no matter how much you feel that they aren't. It's hard to talk someone out of that place so better just to love them in it if you can. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 14480, distribution: 0.6416539980667217 ; Therapy .. // i don't want to be grown up  Somewhere in amongst T talking about how much progress I had made in therapy and how now it was like me leading the way and her following behind me, I managed to say something I've been thinking since Christmas. So this session, when it came up I took the plunge. “I know it's good, that I'm doing so much better now. It's good that I can be my own adult voice and keep myself on track with eating, and even when I am late with a meal or don't want to eat something, I can tell myself that this is what I need to do. But sometimes I don't want to be the one to do that! I miss back when I was unwell, and I would text you in a panic over something I couldn't get out of eating, and you would tell me it would be ok and I could eat it, or I needed to eat it, or whatever. I miss that…. although I do know that it was also awful. I mean, the food aspect made me completely stressed out, and then texting you and reaching out for that connection, made me completely stressed out too, so I know it wasn't a lovely place to be. But I just miss someone else making food feel ok for me. There's part of me that doesn't want to be the grown up with it and have to do it for myself.” By the way, I definitely didn't say it in one long clear paragraph like that. It came out in fits and starts with T prompting and asking for clarification along the way. We've been working together for so long that she knows how to help me keep talking, what prompts to use. I know that she knows, so when I trail off and she gets me going again, I know exactly what she is doing but I submit myself to the process and go with it. It's like a back and forth between the part of me that wants to share and the part of me that wants to protect myself from being vulnerable. T helps the sharing part to keep coming forward. When I'd got it all out and T had understood it, she said I was very brave to say that and she knows it takes courage to admit something like that. I felt relieved that I'd managed to say it all. I know I can't go back to that child-like state where I depend on T to monitor my eating and look after me food-wise and I only ate because T made me agree to do so. I know it was hellish at the time so I don't even want to, but it's the *feeling* of T being so nurturing and caretaking and me feeling so child-like and reparented that I miss. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 13094, distribution: 0.2092687943383984 ; Empty: A Memoir by Susan Burton
 
 So I just finished this incredible book, and I have a lot of thoughts to dump out about it.   It's different from other binge eating books that I've read in that it does not focus on recovery—Burton is upfront about that, and it's basically in the title (it's a memoir, not a guide or explanation). And, a good chunk of it is about her restrictive eating phases before and after her bingeing phase. But it really, really resonated. It's kind of incredible how experiences that you think are unique to you, are in fact common experiences.  Even if this book didn't provide a clear path forward for myself, it made me feel less alone. To quote Burton, who also dove into books about eating disorders while in the midst of her own: “I wasn't interested in the end, the part where she came out okay. I wanted to stay in the part where she was wrecked. I wanted to feel less alone, because isolation had become the primary consequence of what I did, separating myself from the regular people who lived in the regular way” (Burton ). Burton voiced thoughts that I didn't know I had until I read them, and she articulated feelings I've struggled with. Here are some quotes that I felt in my soul, in case they help anyone else: Describing bingeing as “a way to temporarily shut everything out and exist in an altered reality defined by the loosening of restraint. But bingeing deadened feeling and was incompatible with human connection” (Burton ). Later describing binge eating as “a 'short-term escape from an aversive awareness of self'” (Burton ).  I had never conceived of bingeing in that way in particular, but when I read it, it felt right. In the moments of bingeing, it's almost freeing—I'm in a different world where it doesn't matter what I eat, I'm just free to eat and exist and nothing else matters aside from that freedom. But it's not a “freedom” to actively avoid reality and everything it brings. It's caging, it's isolating, and it prevents living my life. I'm actively avoiding existing as myself—my mind, my body, my life feels too uncomfortable (even if that discomfort might just be the uncomfortable “urges to binge” that Kathryn Hanson describes in Brain Over Binge) and I turn to bingeing.  Describing her mother calling out her anger: “My anger had been talked about before. And, yes, I had plenty of it, but it was all at myself. I was angry at myself for all the wrong ways I was. I wouldn't be angry if I were better! If I could just fix myself, this would all end” (Burton ).  God, the anger and self-loathing is so real. On days I binge, or even think about the consequences of previous binges, I just feel like absolute shit, and I'm teetering on the edge of lashing out at everyone around me. But part of me wants to scream that I'm not angry at them, I'm angry at me. And I've convinced myself I just need to “fix myself” and stop bingeing, and then I'll be the perfect bubbly person I want to me. Is this true? Probably not.  “Ten minutes was enough to ruin everything. How was it that in such a small unit of time you could make an entire day into a total wreck?” (Burton ).  Simply put, this quote was just relatable. It feels impossible some days to ever be a “normal eater” when an entire day can be ruined with ten minutes of bingeing. I know that black-and-white thinking is a problem that needs to be addressed, and days can't truly be “ruined,” but it was refreshing to see this account written by someone else—a professional! a writer! a perfectionist, over-achiever like me!—who felt the same way I do.  “Other girls just had their bodies and put food into them and didn't think. Or they did think but in a normal way. I could tell by the way they said it: 'I am getting so fat.' They weren't wrecked by food in the way I was; it didn't define them” (Burton ).
  I felt this one so strongly. Even when I was mostly “recovered” in college, I still envied the girls who could talk about their food or bodies without feeling deeply uncomfortable or shameful in the way that eating disorders mess up your cognitive associations. And I know that's unfair of me; I never know what other people are going through, including with food, and Burton addresses her own experiences with having to challenge her preconceived notions of others and her own self-centered perception of eating disorders. It adds to the guilty and shame, I think—to hate yourself, and to project that anger onto others who seem more “normal,” and then to hate yourself even more for doing so.  “My eating had worsened in distinct stages. Beginning each new level, I'd felt horror that this is the worst it's ever been. Now the worst felt medical. There were times I ate so much food I worried something bad could happen to my body. A line had been crossed: The fear of the harm I was doing was now worse than the humiliation of continuing to expand” (Burton ).
  So much about this book had me yelling internally, “This is me! This is me!”. I can point to specific times when it felt like I'd crossed a bingeing threshold. For example, I would previously never eat at night—not because I was actively avoiding eating at night, but just because it had never really occurred to me to do so, and I didn't have the desire to. Until I did once during a binge, and suddenly it became a new norm. The number of time's I've said to myself, “This is the worst it's been…” Yikes. And Burton specifically discussing the medical fears—I have felt genuinely afraid of the damage I was doing, of the heart palpitations and the stomach discomfort and the severe bloating. I'd imagine how embarrassing it would be to die from bingeing so hard that my stomach bursts, and I get so anxious about the possibility. B.E.D is truly horrible.  Discussing how the life milestone of leaving for college couldn't even feel like an important milestone because of the bingeing: “I could not even contemplate what I felt about leaving home. The only exit I cared about was from the eating. Until I left that, nothing else would matter” (Burton ).  Bingeing takes over your life. I feel like I cannot live fully, I cannot do anything, until I get my eating under control. It just fills my mind constantly: thoughts of food, eating, weight, body, meals. Nothing else seems to matter, and nothing else can matter, until I clear some of the mental space that is currently taken up by bingeing.  Reflecting on her post-binge rituals of writing and setting new never-again goals each time: “It was the first moment I realized that I was getting something from this. That I liked something about this. I liked the possibility inherent in the act. I liked getting as low as you could and then every day the moment of begin-again. I liked the calm that followed an episode. Something quieted, the need met. Ah, yes, here I am in the place where I make resolutions and start afresh” (Burton ). “And it was true that I would miss the cycle of destruction and renewal, so regular that it was circadian” (Burton ).  This really caused me to reflect on my own “destruction and renewal” cycles. It's true—after a binge, there's something ridiculously empowering about setting new goals and resolutions and feeling convinced that it will never happen again because in that moment, it truly feels like a fresh start and a new beginning. Is that part of what keeps the habit engrained? That part of me thrives on the fleeting sense of control, even though I am never able to follow through with those resolutions? Some of my most productive moments have been post-binge, once I get past the self-loathing stage and move on to the resolution, future-oriented stage. I had just never before considered this to be an inherent part of the bingeing cycle…  Describing her constant food thoughts as a sound engineering metaphor: “The eating stuff was a track that ran in my brain under all the other tracks. Sometimes it would get so loud that it would drown out all the other tracks; sometimes I could lower the volume, but I was never able to remove the track from the session. Deleting the track was the wrong idea, [my therapist] said; lowering the volume was good, but the main thing was to boost the other tracks. Boost the other tracks. Develop other strengths and ways to cope; raise the signal on all I'd neglected” (Burton ).  I absolutely loved this metaphor. Food takes up so much of my brain energy and thoughts, and I have been so desperate to clear up that space for other things. But if I find ways to focus on other strengths and cope with life in new ways, the space will clear itself to make room for the new focuses. It's kind of intuitive, so it's not particularly new information, but I wanted to print out this quote and wallpaper my room in it. It gives me hope. 
------------------------------------------------------------

Doc ID: 6381, distribution: 0.1312094096730504 ; “I am not my imperfections”. “Owning our story can be hard but not nearly as difficult as spending our lives running from it. Embracing our vulnerabilities is risky but not nearly as dangerous as giving up on love and belonging and joy—the experiences that make us the most vulnerable. Only when we are brave enough to explore the darkness will we discover the infinite power of our light.” On July , , I celebrated two years sober. Even though I'm a survivor, even though I have not touched a mind or mood altering substance since , even though I have a life beyond my wildest dreams- I was still ashamed for so long to publicly share a fact that made me “less then perfect.” Today I am a little less ashamed because sobriety is what has given me the best moments of my life. Before I got sober I was miserable. A miserable shell of a human who allowed others to treat me like sh*t because that is what I thought-And was broken down to believe- I deserved.

Sobriety has made me emotionally, spiritually and physically (because I actually take care of my body now) stronger, it has open doors that would have remained closed forever, it has literally handed me my dream job, it really has made me believe that there is nothing in this world that I can't get/be if I put the work in, and it truly has saved my life.

In the rooms I have heard the saying- alcoholics are the only people given two lives in one lifetime if they choose sobriety, and I am so damn happy that I have been able to live and love this second life. I do hope this post helps anyone who is struggling who feels all alone in the shame of this disease to know that they so are not alone, that recovery is possible even for the worst alcoholics and I % believe I am that much more amazing in every way because I fight this disease every day.”
.
.

Doc ID: 8856, distribution: 0.05895358962878372 ; a little while back i was told that i am a 
👑self-care queen👑

while i appreciated it wholeheartedly, i also felt conflicted. in my head, that statement  implied “self care” is something extravagant and not something for everyone

but self care is an imperative….
it's a non-negotiable to me

when i'm not taking care of myself / prioritizing myself, the care/attention/love i can give to the people around me is less genuine. i'm more resentful and snappy and unhappy with the way my attention is constantly directed away from my own needs

you can't pour from an empty cup, but it also doesn't feel good to be constantly pouring from a half-full cup. fill that cup all the way! fill it up so much that it's constantly overflowing and overflowing everyone else's cups! fill it up so much that there's not a chance the people around you won't feel it and be inspired to continue filling theirs.

self-care isn't just the thing i do on the weekends when i “have time.” it's the thing i do regularly so that i don't feel neglected by myself. it's the thing that allows me to be present and hold space for other people. 

so if that looks like saying “no” to people, say no
if that looks like being on IG less, be on IG less
if that looks like going out for a walk during your lunch, do that
if that looks like having difficult conversations to set your boundaries with others…. do it. that's what i've been doing lately. 

and what's interesting is that when i got that message i was just coming out of a week of stress and sleep deprivation. i was trying to get back on my self-care extra hard because i saw how my attitude was affecting other people. 

we are all entitled to be self care queens/kings❤️ it's not selfish. it's not self-centered. it's not disregard for others. it's simply showing up for you so you an show up for others. 

how do you show up for yourself on a regular basis?  let me know 👇🏼 👇🏼 👇🏼

Doc ID: 2496, distribution: 0.5248131238800688 ; Happy Real Me Monday! A few years ago, every Monday marked the beginning of a new endeavour to have my “dream body”… But I just wanted to remind you:

🌟 Just because it's Monday doesn't mean you need to start a new fad diet or punish yourself for what you ate or did over the weekend.

🌟 It's not a dream body if it's a nightmare to maintain!! 

🌟 AND the “dream bodies” you see online & compare yourself to probably don't always look like that anyway (take these photos as an example!!)

My dream body now is whichever body I'm in when I'm living my happiest, most balanced life!! 

Giving up diet culture & accepting your body does not mean you're “letting” yourself or your health go. I believe it's actually one of the healthiest things you can do! All bodies — at any size — can engage in health-promoting behaviours that can improve health: reducing stress, joyful movement, intuitive eating, balanced nutrition, therapy/communication, sleeping more, prioritising your inner peace & so on.

Here's a quote I read recently that made me feel all warm & fuzzy towards my own body and reminded me WHY I choose to make healthy choices out of love for my body instead of hate.

You are not too “fat” or too “skinny”.
You are not too “old” or too “wrinkly”.
Your nose isn't too big & your 🍑 isn't too small.
This body has carried you around your whole life.
It's picked you up when you've fallen down.
Fought through colds and flus, broken bones and broken hearts.
Even when you put it down, it just keeps going.
Keeps on working to the best it can.
Through the good & bad, your heart continues to beat.
It'll take you through to the very end.
What a beautiful, clever thing.
And what a beautiful, brilliant person you are.
- by Makaia Carr

You will bloom if you take the time to water yourself 💛

#nevermissamonday #expectationvsreality #embraceyourbody #bodyacceptance #embraceyourself #instagramvsreality #bodyimage #bodyimagehealing #bodyimagemovement

Doc ID: 9475, distribution: 0.5701809825591334 ; ice cream can just be ice cream.
a mirror can just be a mirror.
a scale can just be a scale.
the size pants you buy can just be the size pants you buy.
calories can just be calories.
movement can just be movement.
a nutrition label can just be a nutrition label.
weight gain can just be weight gain.

we label things as “good” and “bad” and put so much power and value in things that have nothing to do with our worth. diet culture and society may try to make you think you are in control of having the “perfect” lifestyle, but there is NO perfect way to live your life.

next time you catch yourself shaming yourself or feeling guilty for what you ate, how you look, or how your body is, ask yourself, where did my beliefs about this come from? and learn to reframe your thoughts.

some examples:

“i can't trust my body because whenever i eat X, i gain weight.” —> “i've broken trust with my body by trying to control it, and weight gain is not inherently bad. my body is on my side, and if it changes size by nourishing it with what it's asking for, then it was supposed to change size.”

“i have to calorie count because i'm afraid of what eating more than X calories will do to me.” —> “calorie counting keeps me from using internal cues of hunger, fullness, and satisfaction. calories are not the enemy. they don't do something to me, they are energy that do something for me.”

“other people eat and workout a certain way, so i'm supposed to eat and workout that way too.” —> “there is no 'right', 'perfect', or superior way to eat or move. that might be for them, but it is not for me.”

“moving my body every day is healthy.” —> “taking care of my body every day is healthy. sometimes that means movement, and sometimes that means rest.”

“being smaller than other people makes
 me better and helps me in life.” —> “accepting my natural body size whatever that may be and honoring what my body needs allows me to focus on living out my purpose which is what will help me live a more fulfilling and joyful life.”

*sorry if you've already seen this! i deleted my initial post and reposted because there was a mistake on one of the graphics and i wanted to change*

peanut butter curry   diced onion

 can full fat coconut milk  cups vegetable stock  cup cauliflower florets
 red peppers, diced

cumin
ginger
cinnamon
curry powder

Doc ID: 6797, distribution: 1.0 ; team sugar cookie always >>

to be completely honest i was one of those kids who LOVED the pink frosted sugar cookies from the grocery store… the ones that literally looked fake hahaha. they're just so nostalgic 🥹

inspired in part by those and also by the cozy holiday season rapidly approaching, i decided to make an everyday, no-bake sugar cookie treat to keep on hand this week. i always have a no-bake snack in my fridge/freezer for my daily sweet tooth and these are such a good mix in the rotation. this recipe is the perfect balance of flavor/pleasure of the real thing and more nutritious, wholesome ingredients. definitely not a replacement for real sugar cookies. if you want the cookie just eat it < 

no-bake vanilla frosted sugar cookie bars

base layer:

- / cup creamy tahini
-  tbsp melted coconut oil
-  tbsp maple syrup
-  tbsp granulated sugar
- / cup oat flour

directions:

add all of the ingredients to a mixing bowl and combine until a uniform, moldable dough forms. transfer this to a brownie tin or a parchment paper lined tupperware and press flat to desired thickness (i made these bars pretty thick so i didn't spread the base layer too much)! place in the fridge to set for a few minutes while you prepare the vanilla frosted layer.

vanilla frosted layer:

- / cup vanilla non-dairy yogurt of choice
-  tbsp room temp vegan cream cheese
-  tbsp granulated sugar   
add all of the ingredients to a bowl and hand whisk until a thick, uniform frosting forms. this took about  minutes for me. 

spread this layer over the top of the base later and top with sprinkles if desired. place in the fridge to set for at least an hour. slice and enjoy!

- tbsp lemon juice
- splash of vanilla

- / cup oat flour
-  tbsp coconut flour 
- pinch baking powder
- pinch of salt

Doc ID: 7246, distribution: 1.0 ; been leaning into simpler meals and my body has been thanking me 🤝 no need to overcomplicate! give me extra toasted bread and something to top it with, i'm golden. sharing an old recipe for some grain-free snacking loaves below! love these as a fun change up, but by no means does that indicate i don't love my real deal bread too 🤪 just love trying all kinds of foods! 
▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️
grain-free snacking loaves (this made  mini loaves, so adjust accordingly):  eggs
/ cup olive oil
 tbsp male syrup 
blend together in a food processor until smooth (can whisk by hand)! add:   cup almond flour
 tbsp coconut flour
 tbsp ground flax
sea salt
garlic powder
sea salt
pinch of baking powder

blend until well combined. pour into mini loaf pans and top with seeds of choice (i usually do sunflower, pumpkin, and chia). bake at  for about  minutes.
.

Doc ID: 6823, distribution: 1.0 ; it's really about time that i combined  two of my favorite foods— sandwiches and banana bread. between the glaze and roasted peanuts on top and the sweet jelly filling inside each slice, this loaf is on another level. 

if you're like me and need a flavor break from all things pumpkin and apple, then you definitely should add this to your baking list this week! 

peanut butter & jelly banana bread

ingredients:

- / cup vegan butter, melted & cooled
-  / cup coconut sugar 
- / cup granulated sugar
-  large eggs
- splash of vanilla extract 
-  large ripe bananas, mashed

- / cup oat flour
- cup gluten free flour
- pinch of baking soda
- pinch of sea salt 

mix ins: 
- fruit jelly of choice
- dry roasted peanuts

heat oven to F and grease a loaf pan. in a bowl using a hand mixer, beat together the butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla until smooth. add the banana mash and mix until uniform. then fold in the dry ingredients and stir until smooth. fold peanuts and spoonfuls of jelly into the mix and transfer batter to the loaf pan. top with more peanuts and jelly (swirled around) and bake for - min. or until golden brown. let cool completely before glazing! for the glaze i just used powdered sugar, a splash of milk, and a small spoonful of jelly all mixed until uniform.

Doc ID: 6852, distribution: 0.6631386079336447 ; a sweet & salty seasonal treat 🫶 my favorite transitional treat between summer and fall. you'd be surprised how well this combo goes together! 

pumpkin s'mores cookies

ingredients:

* / cup creamy salted peanut butter
* / cup granulated sugar 
*  egg
* / cup pumpkin puree
* splash of vanilla 
* / cup gluten free flour
* pinch each of cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice, sea salt, and baking soda
* mini marshmallows
* chocolate of choice

preheat oven to F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. in a bowl, mix together peanut butter, sugar, pumpkin puree, vanilla, and egg until well combined. then add the flour, spices, baking soda, and salt. stir until well-mixed. fold in chocolate and half of the marshmallows. using a cookie scoop, drop the dough on the sheet. add the remaining marshmallows on top of the cookies and press down to set. add extra chocolate on top if desired, then bake for - minutes. remove from oven, let cool and enjoy!

- / cup granulated sugar

- pinch of baking soda
- pinch of sea salt 

blueberries: 
- / cup blueberries 
-  tbsp sugar

heat oven to F and grease a loaf pan. start by preparing the blueberries- toss them with the sugar and place to the side. in a separate bowl using a hand mixer, beat together the butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla until smooth. add the banana mash and mix until uniform. then fold in the dry ingredients and stir until smooth. fold blueberries into the mix and transfer batter to the loaf pan. bake for - min. or until golden brown. let cool completely before slicing!

Doc ID: 7101, distribution: 0.6161700505510035 ; tuesdays are my long days: work, more work, and then late night yoga 🧘‍♀️ you guys know i cant flow without fuel (snacking before yoga is my favorite hobby) so i'm sharing a recipe for my favorite bite at the moment! these NO-BAKE CHOCOLATE COATED CARAMEL SLICES are creamy, dreamy, and packed full of wholesome ingredients to keep me happy happppppyyyy 🥰 that chocolate layer on top 💀💀💀 as always i haven't tried subs unless indicated but i'm sure any nut/seed butter will work here, and same goes for any dairy-free milk. feel free to test different flours and sweeteners but these are so perfect as they are- just saying 🤷🏻‍♀️

no-bake chocolate coated caramel slices:

base layer 

in a food processor blend:
 cup soft pitted date 
 cup oat flour
 tbsp oat milk

once a uniform dough forms, pack this into the bottom of a greased loaf pan and freeze for  min.

middle layer

in a food processor blend: 
/ cup sunflower seed butter 
/ cup melted coconut oil
/ cup of maple syrup 
 large pitted dates
 tbsp maca powder (optional)
pinch of sea salt 
pinch of cinnamon 
splash of vanilla

pour over the base layer and freeze this for  min.

top layer

melt: 
 cup chocolate of choice 
 tbsp coconut oil

i add these two ingredients to a microwave-safe bowl and cook for  seconds. remove, stir until uniform, pour over middle layer, and freeze again. slice and enjoy!

Doc ID: 7282, distribution: 0.8312209383934652 ; some fun food facts about me: i'll always be a soft over crunchy person when it comes to cookies, BUT when it comes to ice cream i'm team hard serve for lifeeeeee. i remember being a kid grabbing ice cream after school with my friends and everyone making a big fuss over me choosing hard serve. is this not a child-friendly choice?! asking for a friend. 🤭 anyway, speaking of childhood, here's my take on those classic iced oatmeal cookies we all grew up with. i really love how i didn't have to sacrifice flavor or texture here while keeping them vegan and dairy-free! for the glaze i just used plain ole' powdered sugar because it's what we had on hand, but feel free to use one of those alt-sweetener powdered sugars if that's your thing.
▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️

vegan soft and chewy iced oatmeal cookies

set oven to . in a small bowl make a flax egg ( tbsp ground flax + tbsp water) mix and let set.

while that's setting, beat together using an electric hand mixer:

- / cup vegan butter (room temp)
- / cup coconut sugar

once that's well combined, add:

-  tbsp date molasses
- the flax egg
- splash of vanilla 
beat until well mixed. then add:

- / cup +  tbsp oat flour
- sea salt
- pinch of baking powder
- pinch of cinnamon

beat again. then add:

- / cup gf rolled oats

once the batter is uniform and sticky, drop spoonfuls onto a parchment paper lined cookie sheet. these spread A LOT (we're going for a thin, sticky, gooey cookie) so make sure there's room for that. i used two sheets. bake for - min. take out when you think they look too underdone (this is KEY). if you over cook they'll burn! i took mine out and let cool COMPLETELY. they'll set really nicely.

once they're cooled, ice them! i just combined  cup of powdered sugar with  tbsp almond milk, mixed to combine, poured over, and put in the fridge to set.
.
.

Doc ID: 6849, distribution: 0.5287762803192262 ; when you're craving pumpkin pie but not all the work that comes with it…

problem solved 😌 no bake, high protein, and vegan too! these were an absolute dream. i hope you love them! 

mini pumpkin pie bites

- / cup creamy salted peanut butter
-  tbsp maple syrup
-  scoops (or / cup) vanilla plant based protein powder
- / cup pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling)
-  tbsp oat flour
- pinch each of sea salt, pumpkin pie spice, and cinnamon

mix all of the ingredients together until a uniform dough forms that holds together well. if the batter is too loose, add another tbsp of oat flour (this might be because the protein powder you used absorbed more liquid). once you have the right consistency, roll dough into balls and add to a plate. i rolled mine in chopped white chocolate but that's optional :) place in the freezer for an hour or two to set before enjoying. store in the fridge for up to a week or in the freezer for a month!

Doc ID: 6712, distribution: 0.4501376628612231 ; don't throw away that one ripe banana!! 

these bites are the easiest no-bake vegan treat— super meal prep friendly too! think banana bread with WAY less clean up. i promise the whole batch won't last very long…

banana bread bliss bites

-  ripe banana, mashed
- / cup maple syrup
- / cup creamy salted peanut butter
-  scoops vanilla plant based protein powder
-  cup oat flour
- pinch each of cinnamon and sea salt

- mix-ins: chocolate chips and chopped walnuts

mashed the banana until uniform, then add in the maple syrup and peanut butter. whisk until smooth, then stir through the protein powder, flour, and cinnamon/salt until a cookie dough texture forms. you may need up to . cups of oat flour (you can also sub more protein powder if you'd prefer, but oat flour will give these more of a cookie texture). once you're able to roll the dough out into bites, roll each one into a ball, add the mix ins, and place on a parchment paper lined plate. transfer the plate to the fridge to set for a half hour and enjoy!

Doc ID: 7027, distribution: 0.8331961795512456 ; every time i see a stuffed chocolate cup i hear the song from the reese's puffs cereal commercial in my head. and if you don't know what i'm talking about… forget i said anything 😄 these JUMBO SALTED ALMOND BUTTER  PUMPKIN STUFFED CHOCOLATE CUPS are a fall dream 🍂🎃🍫 look at the size of these things!!! and the stuffing 🤌 you need these in your life. 

jumbo salted almond butter pumpkin stuffed chocolate cups

chocolate layer: 
-  cup chocolate chips 
-  tbsp coconut oil
  salted almond butter pumpkin filling:

-  soft pitted dates
- / cup salted almond butter
-  tbsp almond milk
-  tbsp pumpkin purée 
- sea salt
- pumpkin pie spice 

directions
* begin by melting / cup of the chocolate  chips with  tbsp of coconut oil in a microwave safe bowl for  seconds. take out, stir a bit, and place back in for another  seconds. stir until fully melted. drop - spoonfuls of chocolate to the bottom of each muffin liner. place the pan in the freezer for set, about  min. while that's setting, add the filling ingredients to a food processor and blend until well combined. amount of blending depends on your texture preference. i liked the little chunks of dates in mine, so i didn't blend for very long. if you're looking for a more uniform texutue, add another tbsp of milk and blend until completely smooth. remove pan from the freezer and add a spoonful on top of the bottom chocolate layer. my filling was sticky enough to roll into balls, so i did that and then pressed them a bit flat onto the bottom layer. do this for each cup and then place back in the freezer to set again, another  min in the meantime, repeat the chocolate melting process from the beginning with the remaining half of the ingredients. remove pan from freezer, pour chocolate over again, and place back in the freezer to set. took about an hour for me!  these tase best thawed for a min or two out of the freezer.

blueberry chocolate chip banana bread  
-  large ripe bananas, mashed
- / cup melted coconut oil
- / cup maple syrup
-  egg
-  tsp vanilla extract 
- / cup gluten-free flour blend
- / cup almond flour
-  tsp baking powder
- sea salt
- cinnamon

- chocolate chips for mixing in
- frozen blueberries for mixing in  
set the oven to F and grease a loaf tin. in a small microwave safe bowl, add about / cup frozen blueberries and microwave in four  second increments, stirring and mashing in between. you'll want the blueberries to be soft and there to be juice present, but keeping some whole for texture. place aside.

in a large bowl, add the wet ingredients and mix until smooth, then stir through the dry ingredients. fold everything together until uniform (careful not to over mix). fold the chocolate and blueberry mash into the batter. transfer to the prepared pan, top with more chocolate, and bake for - min or until golden brown. let cool completely before slicing.

Doc ID: 6694, distribution: 1.0 ; it's been a LONG week for us all… nothing some chocolate can't fix 🥲

we had a ton of ripe bananas to use up so i did what had to be done. 

recipe below— no guarantees this batch lasts more than a day!

double chocolate chip banana mini muffins

preheat oven to F and prepare a loaf pan.

wet ingredients:

-  large ripe bananas, mashed (i used  small ones here)!
- / cup olive oil 
-  eggs 
- / cup maple syrup 
- splash of vanilla

dry ingredients:

-  cup gluten-free flour
- / cup almond flour
- / cup cacao powder
- pinch each of sea salt, baking powder, and cinnamon 

mix the wet ingredients together until well-combined. in a separate bowl, do the same for the dry ingredients. add the dry mixture to the wet and fold until uniform. i stirred through about / cup chocolate chips at this pint. transfer batter to the prepared muffin tin with liners and bake for - minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. let cool completely before enjoying!

/ cup maple syrup

Doc ID: 6838, distribution: 0.7563069591946328 ; i always see homemade cinnamon rolls on my timeline but to be honest they're too much work in my silly little opinion 🥲 if you're anything like me (craves cinnamon rolls but wants a shortcut), this recipe is % for you. hope you love it 🫶

cinnamon roll mini muffins

vegan & gluten free 

this made  small muffins for me!

ingredients:

* / cup of maple syrup
*  medium ripe banana, mashed
* / cup of non-dairy milk
* / cup olive oil 
* splash of vanilla 
*  cups almond flour
* pinch of baking powder
* pinch of sea salt
* pinch of cinnamon

directions:

preheat the oven to F and grease a muffin pan. in a mixing bowl, combine all of the wet ingredients until well combined. add in the dry ingredients (except for the chocolate chips) and mix until uniform. drop the batter into the muffin tin. bake for - min or until golden brown. let cool and ice!

cream cheese icing:

all i did for this was whisk together / cup room temp cream cheese (mine was vegan) with  tbsp vanilla yogurt of choice (also vegan). combine until smooth and fluffy (if too thick, add a splash of milk of choice). spread onto each muffin and top with a sprinkle of cinnamon!

Doc ID: 6766, distribution: 0.8090902606277226 ; heard it was national peanut butter day 👀 aka my super bowl hahaha

i've been making (and sharing!) this recipe for years but it only felt right to reshare it today. this time with a little step by step for you! one of the easiest recipes you can make to have on hand for a wholesome, nourishing snack. i like rolling the dough out into balls too and making bites if you prefer to eat it that way! 

however you make these, i hope you love them as much as i do!  years and counting is a long time to keep a recipe on rotation, so you know it must be good <

 ingredient vegan vanilla peanut butter protein bars

- / cup creamy salted peanut butter 
- / cup plant based vanilla protein 
- / cup almond flour
- chocolate of choice  
line a brownie pan with parchment paper and set aside. mix the nut butter and protein powder together until smooth. add the almond flour and mix until well-combined (may have to use your hands here until a dough forms). mix in chopped chocolate. transfer dough to the pan and flatten out to desired thickness. freeze for about an hour or until firm. enjoy straight from the freezer or slightly thawed for best flavor!

Doc ID: 7192, distribution: 0.6886781533347476 ; it's always pumpkin season if you believe hard enough :') got our first snowfall here in NJ today and i've just been swooning over it since the first flake. that said, i'll be curling up by the fireplace for the rest of the afternoon with a thick slice of this GUT-FRIENDLY GLAZED CHOCOLATE PUMPKIN CAKE LOAF. this recipe is decadent and rich… just like any meal enjoyed on a snowy day should be. i added in @mindbodygreen chocolate collagen+ to the batter to make this cake gut-friendly as well- totally optional but doesn't hurt. i'm clearly on a roll with these chocolate loaf recipes hahaha. file me under “creature of habit” i guess 🧐

gut-friendly glazed chocolate  pumpkin cake loaf

(inspired by @yossyarefi spiced chocolate-pumpkin cake)

 eggs
/ cup coconut sugar

 cup pumpkin purée
/ cup extra-virgin olive oil
/ cup almond milk
splash of vanilla extract

pinch of ground cinnamon
pinch of sea salt
/ cup cacao powder
 cup gluten-free flour blend 
pinch of baking powder
/ cup @mindbodygreen chocolate collagen+ (optional) (code HEALTHFULRADIANCE saves you % on your first order of supps)!

set oven to  and grease a loaf pan. in a mixing bowl add the sugar and the eggs and beat until well combined. then add remaining wet ingredients and mix until thoroughly combined. in a separate bowl mix the dry ingredients, then add dry mixture to the wet and slowly mix until a smooth, silky batter forms. pour batter into the loaf pan and bake for - minutes. let cool completely before slicing! 

glaze is just  cup powdered sugar, a splash of dairy free milk, and a teaspoon of pumpkin purée mixed and drizzled on top! 

.
.

chocolate stuffed peanut butter cookie dough cups

inspired by @blissfulbasil!

cookie dough base: -  cup peanut butter -  cup coconut sugar
- / cup oat flour
- / cup almond milk
- vanilla
- sea salt

set the oven to  and line a mini cupcake pan with liners. using a hand mixer beat together the peanut butter, sugar, and vanilla until well-combined. add the oat flour and sea salt and beat on low until a crumbly batter forms, then slowly add the almond milk on top and continue to mix until batter is sticky. roll into small balls and place in the pan, using your fingers to press an indent in the center. bake for  minutes and then let cool completely (i placed in the fridge for a half hour). chocolate filling: - / cup @enjoylife mini chocolate chips - / cup coconut oil

place in a microwave-safe bowl and melt for  minute. the chocolate chips may not have melted completely, just stir them around in the oil and they'll melt in seconds. when the cups are cooled fill each cup with chocolate. place in the freezer to harden!
.
.

vegan mini chocolate chip banana muffins

this made  small muffins for me!

ingredients:

* / cup of maple syrup
*  medium ripe banana, mashed
* / cup of non-dairy milk
* / cup olive oil 
* splash of vanilla 
*  cups almond flour
* pinch of baking powder
* pinch of sea salt
* chocolate chips of choice

directions:

Doc ID: 6815, distribution: 0.6716643831882784 ; after a few weeks of devouring large batches of my recipes all by myself, it's probably time i pivot to some small batch recipes 🫡

this recipe is perfect if you're looking to whip up a sweet treat without having tons of leftovers. these measurements made six cookies for me, so basically one serving 👀

to be honest these cookies won't last you very long. they're so soft and perfectly flavorful. oh and VEGAN. meaning you can eat the dough before you bake it— major bonus points if you ask me 😚

small batch vegan pb pumpkin cookies

makes !

melt:

/ cup peanut butter
 tbsp coconut oil 

add:

/ cup pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling)
/ cup granulated sugar 
/ cup gluten free flour
sea salt
cinnamon 
baking powder

mix in:

chopped chocolate 

preheat oven to  and prepare a cookie sheet. 

add the peanut butter and coconut oil to a microwave safe bowl and microwave for  seconds. remove and stir until smooth. then add in the pumpkin and sugar and whisk until uniform. fold through the four, sea salt, cinnamon, and baking powder until a thick, uniform dough forms. mix in the chocolate and use a cookie scoop to transfer dough to the cookie sheet. bake for - minutes or until golden brown. let cool to set before enjoying (also amazing right out of the oven they'll just crumble a bit)!

double chocolate brownie batter loaf (gluten free)!

/ cup olive oil
 eggs
/ cup tahini
/ cup oat milk
splash of vanilla extract
/ cup coconut sugar 

. cups gluten-free flour blend 
/ cup cacao powder
pinch of cinnamon
pinch of baking powder
pinch of sea salt

chocolate of choice for topping

set oven to F and grease a loaf pan. add the wet ingredients to a food processor and blend until well combined. add the dry ingredients and blend again until a thick, smooth batter forms. pour batter into the loaf pan and top with chocolate. bake for - minutes and let cool completely before slicing!

Doc ID: 6741, distribution: 1.0 ; i can explain 👀

that first ingredient in the blender? butter beans… yeah... 🥲

but listen!!! tone  fair, you guys absolutely loved my chickpea cookie dough muffins and bars— i'm confident you can add these brownies to the list of 'bean-based desserts i didn't expect to love, but now can't live without' (working title, it's a bit long hahaha). you get the point.

not only do the butter beans give these brownies a rich, fudgey texture, they also pack plenty of protein and literally no flavor. you CANNOT even taste them!

i topped mine with a simple vegan chocolate ganache to really take these to the next level. you can add a scoop of protein powder into the icing too if you're really looking for an extra high protein treat!

details below, really hope this one makes it into your baking rotation soon :)

high protein vegan fudge brownies

in a food processor combine the following:

-  can butter beans (rinse and drained) you can probably substitute any other beans here, but i like the size of these for this recipe!
-  large banana

puree until smooth, then add the remaining ingredients:

- / cup maple syrup
- / cup cacao powder
- / cup chocolate protein powder
- / cup oat flour
- sea salt
- pinch of baking powder
- / cup non-dairy milk

blend everything until a uniform batter forms. transfer the batter to a greased baking tin. bake at F for - minutes and let cool completely before icing. i like to place mine in the fridge to cool since i find they get extra rich and fudgy this way!

while the brownies are cooling, make the chocolate ganache. in a small bowl combine:

- / cup cacao powder
- / cup powdered sugar 
-  tbsp non-dairy milk

whisk until smooth and uniform, then spread over the brownies. place back in the fridge to set before slicing!

#healthyfood #healthy #foodie #foodblogger #peanutbutter #healthyinspo #healthylife #healthymeals #plantpower #valentinesday #chocolate #beans #vegan #healthyfood #chocolate #reels #veganprotein #highprotein #whatveganseat #recipe #brownies #highprotein #ganache #veganbrownies

Doc ID: 6801, distribution: 0.5632164924808734 ; as someone who struggled with disordered eating for years, i've truly come to value the importance of healthy and happy hormones 💓💓

i used to be so afraid to eat high fat foods, which in hindsight is absolutely wild to me. a nutrient dense recipe like this one is now my body's best friend— tasty, nourishing, and satiating. 

a bit of a rant but i hope it reaches someone who needs to hear it today. food should not be feared but rather embraced 🙏

i digress 🤪 this recipe is loaded with many anti-inflammatory ingredients that will help balance hormone levels and keep you happy and healthy— especially during *that* time of the month yayyyy. i've been crumbling these into yogurt bowls or enjoying with a smoothie on the side. just some ideas that hopefully inspire you to make a batch!

snack for healthy hormones 

sweet & salty chocolate bars 

to a food processor add and blend the following:

- - medium soft pitted dates
- / cup raw almonds
- / cup raw walnuts
-  tbsp ground flaxseed
- / cup cacao powder
- / cup chocolate protein powder (this is optional)
-  tbsp maca powder
-  tbsp maple syrup
- **don't add right away, but you'll need water to blend (i add up to / cup in  tbsp increments as the blender is going)

blend everything and slowly add the water as the food processor is running. this will allow a formable, sticky dough to form. once this consistency is achieved, transfer the mixture to a parchment paper lined tupperware or loaf pan and place in the fridge to set for a few minutes. i topped mine with melted dark chocolate (/ cup chocolate chips with  tbsp tahini, melted in the microwave until smooth). i like melting my chocolate with tahini over coconut oil because the result is richer/thicker and it doesn't crack when sliced into!

pour the chocolate over top and place back in the fridge to set. once hardened, slice into bars and enjoy!

Doc ID: 6881, distribution: 0.6957030754373127 ; every summer my dad starts a massive garden— our first zucchinis we're ready so you know what i has to do ☺️

nothing comes close to growing your own food 👩🏻‍🌾 this loaf is extra special to me because my dad's garden is a labor of love 💓 hope you try this one out! the chocolate ganache is truly something else !! 

chocolate ganache zucchini loaf

ingredients:

- / cup vegan butter, melted & cooled
-  / cup coconut sugar 
- / cup granulated sugar
-  large eggs
- splash of vanilla extract 
-  large ripe bananas, mashed

- / cup oat flour
-  cup gluten free flour
-  pinch of baking soda
-  pinch of sea salt 

mix ins: 
-  large zucchini, shredded and squeezed dry
- chocolate chips

whipped icing (these two ingredients whipped by hand until smooth, the placed in the fridge to set until firm)

- / cup chocolate chips (melted with coconut oil until smooth)
-  tbsp vegan cream cheese 

heat oven to F and grease a loaf pan. shred the zucchini and strain with paper towels until the shreds are dry. place aside. in a bowl using a hand mixer, beat together the butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla until smooth. add the banana mash and mix until uniform. fold in the zucchini until uniform. then add in the dry ingredients and stir until smooth. stir through chocolate chips and transfer batter to the loaf pan. top with more chocolate and bake for - min. or until golden brown. let cool completely before icing!

Doc ID: 7224, distribution: 1.0 ; my chocolate cravings the past few days have been next level. i didn't even know a level this extreme could be unlocked 🤯 leaning into that and giving my body what it wants! a fresh batch of these EXTRA FUDGEY BROWNIES w/ CHOCOLATE MOUSSE ICING always do the trick.

extra fudgey brownies with chocolate mousse icing:

set oven to  and grease a brownie pan. 
to a bowl add  flax egg ( Tbsp ground flaxseed +   tbsp water). let sit until gel-like consistency. to that add: -  cup mashed sweet potato
- / cup maple syrup
- / cup salted crunchy almond butter (can use any nut butter here, will change the flavor profile a bit)
- splash of vanilla

mix until a well-combined, then add: - / cup cacao powder
- pinch of sea salt
- pinch of cinnamon (brings out chocolate flavor)

mix thoroughly until a thick batter forms. will seem a bit dry at first but keep mixing, it will come together! mix through chocolate of choice and transfer batter to the brownie pan. bake for - minutes. let cool completely before icing.

icing: - / cup full fat coconut milk
-  tbsp cacao powder
-  tbsp maple syrup
- / of a ripe avocado
- sea salt
- vanilla

blend until thick, will be mousse-like in texture. let set in the fridge for an hour or two before icing completely cooled brownies
.
.
.
.
