Doc ID: 6917, distribution: 0.7927129777285814 ; one of the best desserts i've made in a long time !! 

i could eat the vegan salted caramel by the spoonful. so lush 😭😭😭

snickers fudge brownies

brownies:

*  cup chocolate chips
* / cup vegan butter 
*  eggs
* / cup granulated sugar
* / cup cacao powder
*  tbsp oat flour
* pinch of sea salt
* pinch of baking powder
* splash of vanilla

preheat oven to F and grease a brownie pan. in a microwave safe bowl, melt the chocolate chips with a tbsp of coconut oil in  second increments (i did two) until melted. in a mixing bowl, add the melted butter, eggs, and melted chocolate until smooth. add the remaining ingredients and mix until uniform. pour batter into the pan and bake for - minutes. remove from oven and let cool completely before adding the next layer.

salted caramel layer:

- - soft pitted dates
- / cup salted almond butter
-  tbsp water (can add more if needed to get the blender going)

add everything to a blender or food processor and blend until smooth and creamy. i poured mine into a tupperware and placed it in the fridge to firm up for a few minutes while the brownies were cooling. once cooled, spread the caramel on top of the brownies and top with roasted salted peanuts. place in the fridge to set for a few minutes before slicing and enjoying!

Doc ID: 7583, distribution: 0.32941334489325247 ; the amount of love, support, and genuine kindness i received on my last post has me like this 🥺 i appreciate you guys! i love you all. how badly i want to make each and every one of you a batch of these PUMPKIN SPICED peanut butter oatmeal blondies with MAPLE CREAM CHEESE frosting...you deserve them alllllllll 💫 until i can start a delivery business, find the recipe below! ▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️
PUMPKIN SPICED peanut butter oatmeal blondies with MAPLE CREAM CHEESE frosting (vegan, gluten and tree-nut free)

 cup coconut sugar
 cup runny peanut butter
/ cup pumpkin puree
splash of vanilla

using a hand mixer, blend these three ingredients until moist crumbles form. in a separate bowl, whisk together

 cup oat flour
/ cup sprouted oats
pinch of baking powder
sea salt
cinnamon
pumpkin pie spice
/ cup coconut flour

add the dry mixture on top of the wet, then mix again using the mixer on the lowest setting. slowly add in / cup of almond milk until the mixture moistens up and large clumps form. add more milk if needed! finally stir chocolate chips and pour mixture into a parchment paper lined brownie tin. bake at  for  minutes!

MAPLE CREAM CHEESE FROSTING
/ cup cashews soaked overnight
 tablespoons each: coconut sugar, maple syrup, warm water
splash of vanilla
pinch of sea salt

blend all ingredients until well combined, then allow mixture to set in fridge for an hour before spreading onto COMPLETELY cooled blondies
.

double fudge brownie loaf:

set oven to  and grease a loaf pan. add the following wet ingredients to a food processor and blend until smooth

-  cup roasted then chilled sweet potato chunks (skin removed)
- / cup maple syrup
- / cup creamy salted almond butter
-  tbsp melted coconut oil
-  flax egg ( tbsp ground flax mixed with  tbsp water, sit for ten minutes)
- splash of vanilla

add dry ingredients
- / cup almond flour
-  tbsp cacao powder
- pinch of baking powder
- pinch of sea salt

if the batter is too thick, slowly add up to  tbsp almond milk while blender is running. stir through chocolate chips, then pour batter into loaf pan. top with more chocolate and bake for about - minutes and let cool completely before serving

Doc ID: 7046, distribution: 0.6769980154041021 ; you know how when you go apple picking in the fall you end up going home with five pounds of apples and no plan for them? not this year 😈 these VEGAN APPLE PIE SUGAR COOKIES just scream fall 🍂 they're also melt in your mouth perfection 😛 i whipped up the glaze on a whim and didn't think it'd work but it turned out lovely! details below xxx

vegan apple pie sugar cookies 

set oven to  and grease a cookie sheet. 

cut an apple in half, dice one half into very tiny pieces, and place to the side. you can even toss in a food processor and give a few quick pulses if that's easier! save the other half for snacking later 🤤

 in a bowl add the following:

- / cup coconut sugar
- / cup softened vegan butter 
-  flax egg ( tbsp ground flax +  tbsp water, mix and let sit until gelled)
- splash of vanilla

using a hand mixer, beat these until well combined. then add:

-  / cups gluten free flour
- pinch of baking powder, sea salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, ground ginger, 

stir the dry into the wet until a sticky dough forms. if it's too loose, add another tbsp or two of flour until it thickens up. stir through the apple chunks here! then chill dough in the fridge for a few minutes to set. remove from fridge and use a cookie scoop to drop dough onto the sheet. bake for about - minutes (you'll want these as soft as possible while still being cooked inside). let cool until just slightly warm to the touch before icing. 

for the icing here i just beat  tbsp of the vegan butter with  tbsp of coconut sugar, then spread it on the barely warm cookies. the result was that it melted into a bit of a glaze, which i loved!

▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️▪️
super fudgey vegan cream cheese swirl brownies

set the oven to  and grease a brownie pan (can use a small loaf pan, that's what i did to get this bar shape)! 

in a small bowl, make a flax egg by mixing together  tbsp ground flax and . tbsp water. let sit until thick.

in a serparate bowl mix:
-  cup plus / cup almond flour
- / cup cacao powder
- pinch of baking powder
- sprinkle of cinnamon
- pinch of sea salt

in a microwave safe bowl, add one chopped up chocolate bar (i used @joyalife coconut milk bar) and  tbsp coconut oil. microwave for  seconds, then remove and mix thoroughly until melted. 

to the flax egg, add:
- / cup olive oil
- the melted chocolate bar

pour wet ingredients into the dry mixture and stir until a thick batter forms. if too thick, add up to  tbsp non-dairy milk until a smooth, rich batter forms (but not runny)! pour batter in the brownie pan.

in a microwave safe bowl, add  tbsp vegan cream cheese and  tbsp maple syrup. microwave for  seconds, then remove and mix thoroughly, scoop cream cheese mixture on top of the brownie batter, then swirl in using a toothpick. can swirl some through the batter before you pour it into the pan as well! bake for  minutes and let cool completely before serving!
.

double fudge zucchini cake

ingredients:

*  medium zucchini, shredded and squeezed dry with a paper towel 
*  eggs
* / cup granulated sugar 
* / cup syrup
* / cup yogurt of choice
* / cup olive oil
* splash of vanilla extract  
*  cup almond flour
* / cup gluten free flour
* / cacao powder
* pinch of sea salt
* pinch of baking powder
* chocolate chips of choice

directions:

preheat the oven to  and grease a loaf pan. mix all of the wet ingredients together until smooth, then add the dry and fold until uniform. stir through the chocolate chips and transfer batter to the greased pan. bake for - minutes and let cool completely before icing. i topped mine with a chocolate icing of / cup chocolate chips melted with  tbsp coconut oil until smooth. pour over and let set/harden in the fridge for at least  hours before slicing.

Doc ID: 12959, distribution: 0.33051559117499607 ; sometimes i wonder if this “food thing” is ever going to be easy or simple again. i call it intuitive eating, but is it, really? am i not having more or less the same breakfast over and over again, with slight alterations? it includes all the nutrients i need, it's a good breakfast and i usually don't even want anything else, i like it the way it is. so far, so good. but panicking weeks or even months beforehand when i know i am going to stay at someone else's place, simply because i don't know what i'm gonna have for breakfast there, what about that? recovery is supposed to be freeing, i really have to push myself a little more and get out of my comfort zone. breakfast is the easiest meal currently, at the same time it's the only one i'm so strict about. another important thing i noticed: yesterday in the evening i had frozen berries and mango with a bit of oatmilk (as a snack), it makes for a nice “ice cream”, i wanted to challenge myself though and added a bit of sugar. started a bad process, but there's something else i noticed, it didn't occur for the first time. apparently i am not used to taking in a lot of sugar anymore, i of course include carbs in most of my meals, but simple carbs as in sugar are a bit of a fear food, so i usually avoid that. the thing is, when i do eat something sugary every once in a while, it instantly gives me a bad headache and i feel very sick. and simple carbs like that are considered “'unhealthy”“ anyway, what do i do? do i keep going against my ed, body signals and what is scientifically proven to be healthier, just to get over this fear food? or do i, hm, not? at this point i really don't know what to do, i don't even enjoy very sweet things (only chocolate). does anyone have any advice?

Doc ID: 2425, distribution: 1.0 ; I grew up my entire life thinking I'm allowed certain foods but I can't have other foods, and if I did eat “bad foods”, I'd feel incredibly guilty about it and punish myself for it. 

I'd heard so many comments like this:
“that has too many carbs”
“are you going to eat all of that?”
“I can't eat that, it's too fatty”
“I can't have another banana, I've already had one today”
“that's so bad for you”
etc

And thinking about food in such a black-and-white restrictive way ended up controlling my life for a long while. I turned down invites to eat out with friends, I quite literally put a scale on the table at Christmas to weigh my potatoes to make sure I didn't have “too many” and I was miserable watching others have cake when I told myself I couldn't have any. Until that craving became so prominent and all-consuming that I'd give into temptation, go overboard and binge… Then the cycle would begin all over again. 

That is not a sustainable way of living your life, nor is it necessary at all.

Now, I eat without restriction & no longer give food any MORAL value in terms of “good” and “bad”. 

I can eat a salad, or I can eat some cake, or I can eat both… Because of this, I no longer feel the urge to binge… because I:
Listen to my body
Eat a good balance of nourishing foods because my body & health deserves it
Honour my cravings of those not-so-nutrient-dense foods too (without guilt)
Move my body in ways I enjoy
Don't strive for an unrealistic or unhealthy body
Eat when I'm hungry… and that's healthy for me.

Healthy looks different for every single person on the face of this earth (so if you have a differing opinion that works for you, that's perfectly okay!!) 💛

Food in the video: the @macrmike x Bree Lenehan mug cake range… Still so incredibly proud of this range!! It represents this message so perfectly… An indulgent chocolate mug cake that is both nutrient-dense AND delicious. My code: AMB-BREE will give you % off (& yes it ships worldwide) AD - my own product xo

Audio by @thisisiona_ — I adore her content!

#mmxbreelenehan #foodfreedom #recovery #recoveryispossible #foodie #selflove #positivereinforcement #balanceiskey #balanceiseverything #foodisyourfriend

Doc ID: 9914, distribution: 0.6057805908328601 ; i've still been “all in”, but i don't really think of it like that anymore because it's just become my normal way of eating.
——
when blake and i spend evenings together (most nights), he sits in the kitchen when i cook myself extra meals (or cooks them for me) and walks to chipotle with me when i want a burrito bowl as a snack.  sometimes, he'll eat these extra meals or snacks with me, but a lot of times he doesn't and just gives me company. do i get bothered that i eat significantly more than him even though he's got  inches and  pounds on me? no, because i know our body's dietary needs are SO individual, and if i want food, it doesn't make sense not to go get some.
——
i remember reading something along the lines of:

feeling hungry is like the urge to pee- it's your body's signal of telling you what it needs. if you honor your body by going to the bathroom when it needs to go, why don't you honor your body and eat when it needs food?

next time you catch yourself comparing what you eat to what someone else eats, feeling like you “shouldn't” eat more, or judging yourself for eating, ask yourself “do i judge myself when I need to pee more than someone else? do i beat myself up every time i feel the urge to go? do i think it's better to push off peeing until you just can't hold it any longer?” if you answer no, why don't you apply that same logic to feeling hungry?
——
p.s. i know the comparison isn't exactly equal, and there's a lot of additional science that i'm not acknowledging here, but i found this comparison to be light-hearted, easy to comprehend, and possibly helpful in moments of doubt, so i thought i'd share :) 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 7232, distribution: 1.0 ; eating disorders are complicated. they don't exist in a vacuum. what feels like an incredibly intimate battle is the opposite. when you're sick, every person in your life is too. nobody is untouched by your pain. and this is the heaviest burden.

i was  years old when my relationship with food, exercise, and my body turned toxic. i was an older sister, a daughter, a best friend, a teammate. yet all i ever thought about was me. i planned every meal out for weeks in advance. i wondered how many calories i burned walking to class. i tugged at the waistband of the jeans sliding off my hips, wanting more of me to disappear when there was nothing to spare. 

my sisters, my parents, my best friend, my teammates and coaches- they fell to the outskirts of my life. i had no time in my day to uphold relationships. how could i? when i passed every waking second running circles in my mind over a scoop of peanut butter i ate last week?

i isolated myself. my eating disorder was safe when nobody was around to challenge it. nobody to ask, “didn't you already work out today?” or “why aren't you eating?” or “are you okay?”. in the beginning i missed these people. i missed their love. but my ED promised me great things in their absence, so i let them go. 

i actively struggled with my ED for  years.  years of pain and misery and throwing fits and screaming matches.  years of running away from dinners in public.  years of skipping my sisters' recitals and games, because i would be forced to eat or miss a workout.  years of projecting pain onto everyone, even though at the time this never crossed my mind. 

i thought because i physically isolated myself, that my ED was contained. but it spread like wildfire. i only know this in hindsight, and it hurts, to see colors where i only saw black and white. 

my family and friends hurt deeply for me. with me. my mom used to always say a mother is only as happy as her saddest child. to this day that moves me to tears. 

we never hurt alone, even if we try our best to do just that. if you can't bring yourself to heal for YOU, then at the very least do it for someone else. i promise they feel your pain. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 24962, distribution: 0.7484018028050307 ; of-entropy: 
 One of the shitty things I've learned about restricting is that  
 It leads to binges, but not just because you're hungry. 
It was easier to restrict when you started, want to know why?
Because now you have a hobby that centers around food You don't just get to focus on restriction and not eating, because the subject of food is your life now. 
If you train yourself to think about food all the time, that's a habit now.
 If your every thought centers around what, when, and how you are allowed to eat next, you are going to fail because now your brain is trained to think of food constantly.
The only way to do this without a binge is if you train yourself to forget. Do whatever it takes to forget.
Meal plan (and log) days in advance and have your meals boxed up, day labeled, and easy to bring so you don't think about them as much.
Focus on methods of distracting yourself from food instead of planning around it obsessively.
Again DISTRACT don't obsess
Replace this food hobby you have with all of the better hobbies you'd wish you had. Read, sew, do art, write, do photography, do math or something. Whatever kind of hobby you wish you would do more, do that instead of revolving around food.

If you don't train yourself to stop thinking about food planning all of the time you will binge.

 Do you want to be the kind of person who is talented, intelligent, graceful, well read, and artistic, on top of being skinny? 
 - 
 Or do you want to be that one weirdo who everyone can tell is obsessed with food who seems to eat very little one day and then eat enough for  people and cry about it the next? 
Train yourself to distract from instead of revolve around it.
 Train yourself to stop thinking about it at all or it will come back to bite you as a binge. 
You are what you think about. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 2455, distribution: 0.49282642695990936 ; Reminders that have helped me eat more mindfully, flexibly & without guilt 👇

🥯 Food gives your body the energy to dance, lift heavy things, heal injuries, fight viruses, stand on your own two feet, to read, think, breathe & be.

🍪 Yes, food is fuel & it's important to give your body good quality food, but it's also for enjoyment too.

🌮 You haven't “ruined” anything by giving into your cravings. In fact, honouring your cravings when you have them will likely help you eat it in moderation & not get to a point where you're obsessing over it & overindulging later. 

🍕 Just because food is there doesn't mean you have to eat it all. If you're getting full, you can have a few cookies & put the rest in the pantry, or if you're eating out, ask for a take-away container. Remembering there's no urgency or wastage helps reduce the FOMO which causes a lot of us to keep going until we finish it all.

🍔 The human body is amazing, it's constantly responding to what you put into it, including your thoughts! I'd argue that feeling extreme guilt after eating a burger will likely do more harm to your mental health than that burger could actually do to your physical health. 

🧘🏻‍♀️ Try eating more mindfully, not mindlessly. To me, eating mindfully is acknowledging my hunger, listening to it, enjoying what I eat & then also listening to the fullness cues that my body sends me when I've had enough.

🥂 Just because you've eaten a less nutritious meal doesn't mean you have an unhealthy diet. “Your dosage is your poison” AKA having too much of anything probably isn't great, but finding that right balance of what works for you & makes you feel good is key!

🍌 Eating too little can cause you to feel tired, down, lack motivation & cause your metabolism to adapt/slow down. It's so important to eat ENOUGH, so that you can function optimally!

🥒 Your body IS going to fluctuate & change over the years. It's inevitable. So be kind to yourself. If you want to make changes, fine! But please don't risk your health for a physical appearance. It's your home & the only one you'll have. Treat it well 💖

Sound: @emmachamberlain 
#foodfreedom #recovery #flexibleeating #foodie #foodislife #eatwithme 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 1349, distribution: 0.2974077805120549 ; honeyvertebrate:imtrying-butimpissed:Look man. No matter what size you force yourself to be, you will hate what you see and feel like shit. If youre trying to survive on nothing you will feel like trash emotionally and physically. Why are you so fucking depressed??? Cuz your brain cant take the bullshit. Any brain surviving on XXX will % be a very upset brain. You cant Happy yourself out of that. You dont have the energy to do that. Fucking eat. The biggest hurdle but the most important step to recovery, is letting go of a sick body. You NEED to gain, you need to let go of controlling your body. A healthy body is nourished. A healthy brain doesnt obsess over sizes and numbers. Its not that simple yes it is. Eat. Force your Ed to shut the fuck up. Cry if you need. Scream if you need. But just fucking eat. Your emotional well being, physical wellbeing, and mental health will all improve as you begin actually feeding your brain and body. Duh. Fucking duh. I absolutely see where you're coming from, and being where you're supposed to be physically works wonders on your mind - but in order to really let go of a sick body, you'll need more than just nutritional restoration. I knew I had to eat enough to keep my body alive for years, but the lack of resources for my mindset just invalidated the hell out of me and kept me sicker. I definitely think getting therapy cannot be ignored in recovery. Absolutely people need mental help to get better. Its the physical part a lot of people tend to slack on. Just therapy isnt enough. You cant heal unless you work on both your brain and your body.

Doc ID: 9721, distribution: 0.26297293213298956 ; i am someone who fully believes in overeating and not prioritizing eating healthy foods as part of the vacation experience. overeating at any time (even at home laying in bed) is not a bad thing and something i do at home too! but, when i travel, eating all 👏🏽 the 👏🏽 food 👏🏽 is something i like to do consciously and with ZERO regret, guilt, or shame.

in the past when i'd travel, i'd feel the need to “prepare” beforehand and would be scared about gaining a few pounds during. while it's definitely possible that i gain some weight when i vacation, the real question is how does that matter??? and the answer is that it doesn't because gaining weight isn't a bad thing!! i also trust that my body knows how to take care of itself, and if ~health~ is the concern, i trust that whatever food my body craves when i'm back at home (this is not just limited to fruits and veggies) and weight my body decides it wants to be at (whether it's less, more, or the same) is what's healthiest for me.

you are meant to have fun on vacation!! whatever that looks like for you, choose it, enjoy it, and remember that you don't have to let intruding thoughts about food or your body take up more space than they need to.

my typical homemade meals, veggies, and sobriety will be there when i'm home, making memories won't.

Doc ID: 12986, distribution: 0.21077849182097821 ; this is hard breakfast is nothing to worry about anymore, when i sit around afterwards i still struggle with feelings of guilt, but i never ~seriously~ considered purging it, and varying ingredients don't really scare me anymore either. Doc ID: 16941, distribution: 1.0 ; Therapy .. // repair // part one  “The first half of last week's session was very confusing. It felt like you had forgotten everything we've talked about over the last seven years…. or maybe like you'd forgotten who I was.” I said it in a bit of a rush. Straight away T said in a surprised sort of voice, “Oh dear, I'm so sorry about that. I apologise for that.” I've no idea whether she was expecting me to bring this up, or whether she felt last week's session went great. I don't know whether she'd thought back on the session and wondered what happened. “You have spent the best part of a year reminding me that when I weighed X I was much less obsessed with eating disorder thoughts and I felt that it was an ok weight. But now I've got back to X and I don't like it and it feels difficult, and suddenly you start talking about losing a couple of pounds.” T explained where she thought she had been coming from when she said that. I can't even really remember how she explained it though. She said she definitely wasn't saying I needed to lose a couple of pounds.  “Faith, listen, this is my responsibility though, what I said and what happened. I'm not trying to put it on you in saying this. I'm just trying to explain where I think I was coming from. I need to take it to supervision and work out what was going on for me.” I carried on by saying how I felt she wanted me to stay thinner and was worried about me getting fat. That she was policing me to make sure I didn't gain too much weight, and how that feels just like what my mum did. T said she didn't mean to be doing that at all and she was really sorry. I said in all the time we had been working together, which is  years, I have never been anywhere near overweight. Gaining too much weight has never been a problem, so I don't know why she kept talking about losing weight. I have enough of a drive in my head to lose weight without T joining in. I said again that if I start talking about needing to lose weight, it's % that it's the eating disorder talking. T got that.  “So when you said you had got to X weight and it felt uncomfortable, you just needed me to tell you that you would be ok, that you could tolerate it.” I nodded. Finally she understood. Even though I know I had said almost those exact words to her last week and she missed it completely, this time she heard me.

Doc ID: 9547, distribution: 1.0 ; one of the most underrated aspects of food freedom and intuitive eating: eating boring foods

today has been a busy and tiring work/study day for me, and one of the many things that intuitive eating has allowed me is the ability to NOT need food to always feel exciting or “hit the spot” perfectly.

in the past, i always felt like every meal or snack i had needed to be exactly what i wanted otherwise the food felt “wasted”, but now that food feels abundant, and my brain knows that there's always more food available and coming, i don't need everything i eat to feel ✨amazing✨.

sometimes, that means eating pizza for lunch even if it's not what i'm craving because it's what's being served at a meeting. sometimes, that means making a recipe, not having it turn out well, but eating it anyway. sometimes, that means eating cold mediocre leftovers because they're there. sometimes, that means going out to eat, not seeing anything on the menu that sounds super great, but ordering something and enjoying the meal experience.

today, that's meant throwing random stuff that doesn't really go together on a plate because it's fast and convenient.

food freedom allows for so many fun and exciting moments with food, but when food is also JUST FOOD, not EVERY experience needs to be one of them.

*photo from last week because i definitely am not taking the time to boil jammy eggs today lol* 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 9750, distribution: 1.0 ; contrary to popular belief, i strongly believe that binge eating disorder is also a disorder of restriction.

based on my personal experience, other people's testimonies, and the research literature analysis that i've done, frequent binge eating is very often a result of restriction, and it's essentially your body's survival tactic. if your body thinks that it's starving or going to starve, and there's food available everywhere around you it's going to instinctively want to eat everything (think: at the beginning of quarantine when everyone excessively stocked up in fear). it's not a lack of willpower, but rather, your body trying to help you. when guilt followed by restriction (even if it's mental restriction) occurs after a binge, this can cause a repeated cycle to occur. breaking out of this cycle isn't a matter of willpower around food, but rather a matter of breaking the restriction that leads to the binge eating.

i think there's a lot of stigma around binge eating-  according to @neda, binge eating disorder is the most common eating disorder, yet in the recovery community on this platform, it seems to be the least talked about.  all disordered eating struggles are valid, and if you are struggling with binge eating, let me tell you that binge eating in and of itself is NOT a bad thing, so you don't deserve to let the fear, guilt, and anxiety of binge eating consume parts of your life.

give yourself permission to let go and move forward after a binge, be the supportive and empathetic friend to yourself that you have the power to be, and if you binge again, it doesn't mean you've failed, so keep going. the goal isn't to never over eat again, to even never binge eat again, or to control the way you eat at all because the more distant i get from my ED, the more i realize that the goal has never been about what or how i eat. the goal is to not let your eating control you, so that you can live your life to its fullest. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 15215, distribution: 1.0 ; Question: You say your friends staged an intervention but how? Did they notice a difference in you? I only ask because I want to talk to my colleague about her eating disorder Answer: It all unfolded over a long period of time. They watched me lose a lot of weight after the birth of d over  months or so. I was deep deep in denial of a problem. Then I lost control of restricting and started bingeing and purging and regained some weight. At this point I confided in two friends because despite my best denial, I knew the purging wasn't normal. I never really stopped purging but with some accountability I got it a bit more under control. A couple of years passed in which the eating disorder mostly flew under the radar, before several emotionally difficult events all occurred within a couple of weeks ago and sent me into a total downward spiral. I'd been able to speak about the eating disorder to a couple of other friends by this time and they were all speaking to each other (I found out later) as to how to help me. One friend had a contact at our church who was a therapist and to cut a long story short (she did also try and pushed me to try the local eating disorder charity for help) she spoke to the therapist, made an appointment and then rang me up and told me what was happening. She picked me up in her car and drove me to the appointment then sat in the waiting area till I went in. Then she did it again the week after.  And that was how I ended up in therapy.It's very difficult to talk to someone out of the blue about an eating disorder. For a long time, the more my friends tried to challenge me, the more I dug my heels into denial. One of the more effective things anyone did was to say “I can see you're struggling, if you want to talk about it, I'm here.” She then refused to enagage in any of my arguments that I was fine, just repeated that when I was ready, I could let her know and we'd meet up for a chat. I hope some of that is helpful for you with your colleague.

Doc ID: 15698, distribution: 0.5725223417771181 ; Therapy .. // ways therapy can help with disordered eating  We started with going through the list of ways therapy can help with disordered eating. We were going to do this last week but then it got sidelined by T's retirement news, so we agreed that we would look at it this week. Here's the list as we discussed it. . Regular eating - It has taken several years to achieve this, but I think this is now pretty good. We talked about how completely chaotic my eating was when I started therapy and how it's been two steps forward, one step back a lot of the time but that we finally got there and have stayed there for a few years now. I acknowledge that I still miss a meal here or there but not very often and generally it's due to life getting in the way rather than intentionally choosing to restrict. My regular eating really is quite stable. T said she had observed every time we fostered a new baby, meals went a bit wonky and eating disorder thoughts crept in and so although I do get back in track, I just need to be aware that's a vulnerable time and be careful. . Fear foods - I'm not afraid of fat any more, I do quite well eating things with fat in now. I'm more afraid of carbs now but I do eat some and I know if I am doing exercise I need more carbs because it feels much better to exercise with adequate fuel. This is how we got onto the hot chocolate conversation. I have a more general fear of deviating from my routine of  meals, and I find it really difficult to permit myself to eat extra spontaneous calories between meals.  . Bingeing, purging, overexercising - I haven't thrown up for years now, December  was the last time. T said “And you never really had a problem with laxatives, did you?” And I looked at her. Uh, maybe not since I've been seeing you, but before that I did have quite a bad laxative habit.  . Learn to manage emotions. T said “Yes you've got lots better at that. Especially managing emotions here in the therapy space, you didn't used to be able to do that. If I said something that upset you, you couldn't tell me. But now look, you can tell me that what I said isn't helpful!” I used to get overwhelmed when things happened in my life - my eating disorder was very good at numbing all that out, and after I started eating again, then when things went wrong I didn't have any coping strategies. I used to be really dependent on T to help regulate my emotions in a crisis. But I don't think I've needed her to do that for quite a while now. . Understand your past. Well I think we've talked about a lot of things, I guess there's always more stuff you could talk about but I think I'm doing ok. T agreed that we have thought about my past together a lot and she thinks I understand it quite well. . Root out faulty thinking patterns - T said she knows I still have some faulty thought patterns. She said maybe we'll come back to this one! . Improve body image. I said that I don't think I have a terrible body image. There's parts of my body that I don't like but I try to accept them because I like what my body can do. I like being strong and able to run fast and feel fit. T had some different idea of what body image meant that she though I still struggled with, but I can't remember what it was now.

Doc ID: 15860, distribution: 0.22359547228307491 ; Question: What was it that made you choose and do recovery. I'm on the fence all the time and wonder what is it that will give me that push to choose full on recovery.  Answer: I don't think there was ever a magic moment where I said right! everything is recovery from this point! When I started therapy, all I wanted to do was get control over my bingeing and purging. I wanted to be able to eat like a normal person - go out for a meal without it turning into a disaster. I didn't want to stop restricting or gain any weight though. Gradually as one aspect improved and I felt better, I was motivated to work on the next thing. I discovered how nice it was to live without all the negative impacts of restriction - to feel warm again! to not be snappy with my family! That motivated me not to fall back and to keep pressing forward.My therapist has been a big help, gently pushing me forward all the time and holding my progress when I slip back.I think what I'm saying is for some people there is a moment where they fully commit to full recovery and just go for it, and that's fantastic. I'm more of a little by little person, so taking baby steps towards recovery worked better for me. I feel like it's built me a solid foundation so that even when I slip, I have lots of ground underneath to catch me. Different things work for different people so only you know what will work for you and also you may need some trial and error to see what that is. But don't do nothing! Take the risk and try something and see how it goes. If it doesn't feel right at least on some level, try something else. Go for it x

Doc ID: 9534, distribution: 0.7098117142896134 ; when i first started my food freedom journey, i honestly didn't think i'd ever actually desire eating vegetables because for a long time into my food freedom journey, vegetables just didn't sound appetizing.

backstory: i restricted my food intake for years, and for a lot of those years, i also struggled with binge eating disorder that was perpetuated by restriction (physical and mental) and feelings of guilt and shame.  restriction for me didn't mean that i didn't eat, but rather, i saw the foods i ate in numbers, and vegetables were something i was constantly eating in very large quantities because they simply meant i got to eat more volume. 

when i finally decided to listen to and honor my hunger and cravings, it felt like the only foods i wanted to eat were the foods i would binge on - aka all the things i viewed as “bad” and would restrict - and i was always eating them in what seemed like extremely excessive amounts.

i remember thinking i was becoming an unhealthy person by honoring my hunger and cravings, but i can look back and confidently say that doing so and releasing all expectations of what intuitive eating “should” look like was the healthiest thing i ever did for myself.

it took time and patience, but now that my body trusts me to honor it, vegetables are a food i actually ENJOY eating, and gentle nutrition is something i'm able to incorporate with no feelings of morality attached.

some days of eating look something like this:
🥞🍕🥯🍨🍝🍩🍫
some days of eating look something like this:
🥦🍳🥗🐟🍠🫐🥑
some days of eating look something like this:
🥞🍕🥗🥯🍨🐟🍠🍫

ALL days of eating are acceptable and have nothing to do with my worth.

disclaimer: my journey was not nearly as smooth and easy as this caption may make it seem, and everyone's healing and road to recovery looks different. the point of this caption is that what healthy eating looks like for you may not be what you think it “should”, and RECOVERY IS WORTH IT.

plate deats:
bed of spinach,
roasted rainbow carrots,
sautéed baby bella mushrooms,
crispy smashed potatoes,
+ trader joe's mahi mahi burger

Doc ID: 9127, distribution: 1.0 ; recent question: do you have tips for food that reduce your appetite?

here's the secret... ALL foods reduce your appetite because your appetite tells you that you need food! when on a plant based or honestly any way of healthy eating, eating a “regular” and “healthy” amount might be difficult for you because you're basing “regular” off of someone else!!! I used to feel weird about eating so much more than my friends during school especially when we'd go out to eat and they'd get full from  tacos but i'm over here still shoving my fifth taco in my face (recalling those post high school taco tuesday-days). it took some time to come to terms with it but the way your body responds to food is so different than the way mine will and the way your parent's will. the healthy and regular amount YOU need is dependent on how you feel.

giving yourself the unconditional permission to eat might seem scary because you may fear you won't stop eating— but you will!! research shows that people will tire of eating the same kind of food (habituation): the more a person is exposed to a particular food the less appealing it comes. the only way to make peace with what you're eating is to go through the experience and to actually eat what you're wanting without holding back. for example if you want to eat three bowls of oats right now but will only allow yourself the “standard” one bowl of oats, your brain will keep thinking about how much it wants those extra two but shouldn't have it. one day you end up cracking and eating ............. and then beat yourself up for it. but if you allow yourself to go for however many bowls you want, there's a big chance you won't be eating  bowls every. single. time.

basically, I don't try to control what I don't have control over... and (I learned this the hard way) I don't have control over my appetite. I just have to be friends with her 😬😬

Doc ID: 9806, distribution: 0.6857498584767358 ; how did i get to this place of freedom with food? i chose to trust the process of allowing myself to eat with no rules and judgement and just did the damn thing.

i eat without a ton of thought most days now. sure, i use some of my outer wisdom to help guide my choices (making sure i eat enough even when i don't “feel” hungry, eating after i workout to help my body recover, knowing what food combos make me feel my best, etc.), but for the most part, eating's pretty easy for me because i eat whatever i want whenever want.

giving myself full permission to just eat without judgment wasn't always as easy as it is for me now though. in fact, it was exhausting, hard, and scary AF.  i went through years of wanting to commit to doing it and then giving up and restricting again.  even after i finally did commit once and for all, i would still have mental battles when i would to eat more, question everything i was doing when it seemed like i had never ending hunger, and constantly debated going back to old restrictive ways.

in those moments of doubt though, you have to keep going because i PROMISE you that if you stay the path, it won't always be that way.

i gained weight doing it (spoiler alert: it's not a bad thing), and i received a few negative comments in the process, but guess what? my life is SO much better for it #foodfreedomforevaaa

Doc ID: 2563, distribution: 1.0 ; Food is energy, not the enemy… Come EAT WITH ME 🍔🍟🧋🥰

I took this the other day on my solo date & left it in my drafts but I thought, you know what? This is a really important topic, I'm gonna post it.

Here I am, eating in public & now online for ,+ of you to see, right before I went dress shopping, because guess what? You don't have to avoid eating before trying on dresses. You don't have to avoid eating whatsoever. It's so important to remember that food is energy, it's the fuel that keeps your body pumping blood around your body, your brain functioning, your lungs breathing. It fuels everything your body does in every second of every day.

Not only that, it's also just really dang delicious and enjoyable, which is not a bad thing. Food is there to be enjoyed, you don't need to live on salads or opt for capsicum instead of bread. You can enjoy a balance of all the foods that are good for your body and also good for your soul.

All of this is coming from a girl who used to be afraid of everything she's doing in this video… eating out, eating a large meal, ordering what she wants from the menu, sitting alone in public, eating in front of people & eating before trying on clothes (bc the bloat is REAL after a meal) but why did I grow up seeing all of those things as something bad? Something to fear or feel ashamed of?

So please, if you're watching this & thinking “I wish I was able to do that” I'm gonna stop you right there & remind you that it all starts with a shifting of the mind, so when that thought pops up next, catch it & start saying “actually, I hold the power, and I believe I can. I know food is good for me, I know I can have a good relationship with food & this is the beginning of a full, flexible, balanced & happy life” 

If you're with me, leave a lil “💛” below 👏🏻 

Also side question, when eating a burger & fries, do you eat the burger first or the fries? Lmk with a “🍔🍟” OR “🍟🍔” or do you do what I do & alternate between everything as you go? HAHA 🍔🍟🍔🧋🍔🍟🧋

 i keep trying to tell myself that hunger is only a temporary feeling, and it comes in waves. but man, these waves almost have me on my ass. im so sick of fighting againsg nausea. worst feeling in the world. if my teeth werent fucked id be initiating my own vomit as to make myself feel better faster, and just get it out, but its futile.  theres nothing to even bring up.  
 chills. sweats. nausea. chills. sweats. nausea. just riding these waves. there goes my entire week. frustrated with a lot of things right now but ive done so much typing today that i just need to stop. elaborating isnt going to solve anything. i just need to get my plants taken care of and not pass the fuck out and ill be okay. cant wait for the day that im financially stable and can afford to have food in my house at all times. sick of having to sacrifice my own nutrition. i dont mind putting my animals first and feeding them first, that doesnt bother me. i will ALWAYS find a way to feed my animals and make sure they have their medicine until the bittetsweet end. but its disheartening not being able to eat because bills come first. if i keep going like this ill die and i wont be able to pay my bills or take care of my animals.  probably gonna go weigh myself on the way to the garden since the scale is down there. out of morbid curiosity. probably gonna be disappointed. always am. i can tell ive lost again. which is unsettling.  it sucks not being happy with your body no matter what you weigh.  lbs, im unhappy because i feel too skinny and weak and my brain functioning starts getting inhibited. doesnt feel good.  lbs, and im unhappy because i feel too squishy and slow. it takes a lot of fucking food to even get to that point, which makes me feel gluttonous n awful because i loathe the feeling of food digesting especially lots of it at once. i tell myself weight gain is what i want, and then ultimately it just doesnt feel right. and then everything else in between, i still feel unsettled in my own skin. ill tell myself i need to gain, and then i do, and i hate it. so ill lose, and ill hate that too. theres no winning. i wish proanas ( even the ones who dont realize they are ) would shut the fuck up and listen to what i have to say for once. i wish people understood that they dont actually want this. what you see on the surface of skinny, is not the reality behind skinny. literally i would give anything just to be a healthy weight and not have to agonize so hard over this. but the people who need to hear that, absolutely will not listen lmao.

Doc ID: 16041, distribution: 1.0 ; Therapy .. // part one // lists and learning curves  We started off talking about weight and eating. Actually, first T asked me if I wanted to keep going down the list of how I wanted things to be different between H and me, and I said I had another list for this week, but it was kind of connected to the other list. I appreciated that T remembered about the first list, because she'd forgotten about it last week. Last week was the first session back after a break and I don't think her head was quite in the game. My list for this session was  . Eating/weight,  . Texting dilemma,  . Are you following where we've come from/where we are going because last week you seemed to have forgotten.  I imagined I would get  and  out of the way quite fast and then move onto  which would lead back into the first list. In the end we never got onto  so the connection with the first list didn't get made, but that's ok. I'll start with it next week. I told T that I had weighed myself and what the number was. I always find it hard to talk numbers (for most of last year, I texted her the number weekly so that I didn't have to say it out loud) and I sometimes freeze up when it comes to actually saying it, but this week I pushed through. I talked about my carb-increasing experiment, and she was very positive about that. “You're learning to trust your body and respond to what it needs. Which is something you didn't learn in childhood. You're doing well!” I gave T a wonky smile when she said this. It is such a long learning curve but I can see that I am making progress. I often use T's words to coach myself when I'm struggling with food choices or allowing myself to eat. I remind myself I'm learning to trust my body and to eat what it needs or wants, rather than imposing external rules on it. Sometimes I manage it and sometimes I don't. The times I don't frustrate me because I know that the more I push through, the more my body and I will learn to trust each other. When I use ed behaviours rather than listening to my body, I'm making it harder for myself to achieve that trust. Still, overall I am making progress and that is really good. No one ever said it would be easy. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 16832, distribution: 1.0 ; Therapy .. // a shift in approach  
 T said something quite radical to me. She said “I had a thought this week. How would it feel if you were to gain to X, and then just stay there at that weight and see how it felt?” I was a bit lost for words. T has never suggested anything like that before! She knows I am really scared of weighing X. This whole therapy rupture came about because I was only a few pounds off X, and I needed T to hold me there because I was panicking about it, and unfortunately she dropped me instead.  Her suggestion really set off a firework of contradictory thoughts inside me. I will confess there was a part of me that was quite excited by the idea. The thought of this stretch opening up between the weight I am now and X, a whole lbs to potentially gain. I liked the idea of a target being that far off, and no longer having to panic when my weight goes up even just one pound from what it is now. It felt like gaining some breathing space from the eating disorder's tight control. Then of course, straight after that thought came the panic of that was all very well but how will I cope weighing X. My clothes won't fit. My bones won't feel so sharp. More fat will creep under my skin.  Even while I was panicking, part of me loves that T made this suggestion. She listened to what I said to her when we had our first conversation about the rupture, that maybe I needed to weigh more [the figure I gave in my rant would put me at a bmi of ] in order to have healthier thoughts, and that maybe even though I wouldn't feel so physically comfortable at that weight, maybe I would realise I need to weigh that in order to be free from the eating disorder thoughts.  I think me saying that really shifted her viewpoint. I've talked before on here about feeling like T wants me to stay thinner, and T valuing control over our own weight and body size. She has never really pushed me gaining weight and she has talked about not wanting me to get overweight again. But I haven't been “overweight” for  years now, and in those  years, and especially the  since I've been seeing T, my struggles have been much more with restricting and losing weight and weighing too littler. ANYWAY, all that is to say that T suggesting I consider intentionally gaining up to a weight that's higher than I've been maintaining at marks quite a change in her approach. I don't want to do it but I really like that she suggested it. And I totally see the logic behind it, that I'm terrified of being that weight, yet maybe if I got there and maintained at that weight, the number would lose its power over me. I had all these thoughts in my head during the session, although none of them were quite as clearly formed as I've written them out up there. It felt overwhelming, bits of me scared to say what other bits were thinking. Eventually I said to T, “Can we talk about something else please?” T said “Yes, of course. But before we do, can you just tell me what was difficult about that? Was it x or was it y?…. I won't ask you any more about it, but it would be helpful for me to know.” [I can't remember what the x and y options were! They might have been something like x was 'there were too many thoughts in your head and it's too hard to think about all of them right now' and y was 'that's a terrible idea and I never want to speak of it again'.] I said it was x. T said that was ok and thankyou for telling her, and then she changed the subject just like I'd asked her to. I think everything in this post was the most important part of the whole therapy session.

Doc ID: 9767, distribution: 1.0 ; my life is not even close to “perfect”, it's not very exciting, and i am definitely not happy and joyful all the time, but at the end of the day, i love it and am so grateful for it.

sometimes i forget all the pain and hardship that i've been through to get to where i am now. while i still struggle with mental health and have moments when life feels really hard, i can confidently say that my low points now are still better than my high points when i was in the depths of my eating disorder.

it can be easy to romanticize eating disorders and to think that times when you were thinner or had a sense of control, life was better. i know i've had those thoughts. truth is, life for me during my eating disorders sucked pretty hard. i was a manipulative liar, i missed out on so many experiences that i will never get to have, i couldn't develop long-lasting relationships, i was in a toxic relationship with myself, and my entire mind was consumed by thoughts around food, my body, and numbers.

when things get hard now, remember to keep choosing LIFE. going backwards isn't an option, so what are you going to with your next step forward? there is so much life out there, and you deserve to live it, like really truly live it, to its fullest. i promise the fight to break free is worth it. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 9577, distribution: 0.6275940514949764 ; i've officially decided that if i could only eat one food for the rest of my life, it would be oatmeal...or pasta. something about how warm and cozy it is, how good it makes me feel in my body and my soul when i eat it, and how much i can change it up day to day just makes it such a staple meal for me.

what's really cool about intuitive eating and food freedom to me is how much more in tune i am with my body now. in the past, i saw food as numbers, and there was a complete disconnect between my mind and my body. i used to have  idea what meals would make me feel good, and i'd go into every meal starving and end every meal either STILL starving or absolutely stuffed- there was no in between.

i thought trying to be in control of my body by controlling my food was the way for me to take control of my life, but that false sense of control really made me become completely out of control, disconnected, unaligned, and lost.

sometimes i take how far i've come for granted, make the journey that got me to where i am seem easy, and forget to acknowledge that for a lot years, i lived with constant feelings of self-hatred, dread, hopelessness, guilt, shame, and fear that fully took over my ability to feel in tune with my own body, be my authentic self, and truly live my life.

choosing to heal can be one grueling process (i don't want to romanticize that), but i promise it really does get better. when you make decisions, ask yourself: am i just choosing to listen to my thoughts (that may or may not have my best interest in mind)? or am i truly choosing myself?

keep choosing yourself over and over and over until you feel like you again.

oats cooked with almond milk, egg whites (makes it so much fluffier), + @ancientnutrition vanilla protein, vanilla greek yogurt, and topped with sautéed pear w/ cinnamon, and @abbysbetter honey almond butter

Part of the problem is that making my own food and eating is just very low on my priority list. Breakfast can happen at any time.  I messaged my friend last night for some accountability and today I will make sure I am more structured and intentional about getting meals in. I want to be able to rebalance myself without needing input from T, because that is what recovery is eventually about isn't it? Doc ID: 11294, distribution: 0.5415832371916113 ; I never thought I would have gone through an eating disorder, never in a million years . . . But . . . I did. 
Many of you guys will know that I went through a pretty roughy period in my teens. I had serious body image issues, obsessed  over calories and severely restricted my food intake. It led me to lose friendships, lose my love for dance and lose the person that people knew as Holly. That crazy girl on YouTube you know now 🤷🏻‍♀️ I found it extremely difficult to open up about what was going on inside my head, and even now I find it hard to explain. I also had no motive to want to help myself, and I saw the rest of my life living that way. In my mind there was just this constant desire to look 'thinner' and eat less. But without any particular 'goal' when would it ever end? 
Ok . . . so THANK GOODNESS I never reached the point of having to be hospitalised. Just as I cannot tell you what triggered my eating disorder, I also don't know exactly what helped me recover. But what I do know is that it started with a change in MY mentality, and nobody else could do that but ME. I changed the way I viewed food and I changed the way I viewed my body. Food become fuel and my body was something to be appreciated, accepted and LOVED. 
Now all this has also taken time. For sure, it did not happen over night. I am also aware that many of you guys out there may have experienced something similar. I opened up about this on my channel quite a while back now, and I would really like to do more to help you. If you, yes you behind the screen right now, is struggling, then I really hope you find the strength to want to help yourself. Likewise, if you know a family member or a friend who is struggling, I hope you can try to help them as best you can. If you have any questions then feel free to leave them below and I can try to answer them, but I am definitely going to be posting more content related to this subject. 
You ONLY LIVE ONCE you know guys, so please don't waste it ✨#eatingdisorderawarenessweek 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 9873, distribution: 0.6822005014093647 ; developing a healthy relationship with food takes TIME.
——
it's christmas eve, and i know that the holiday season can be really hard for those of you who are struggling with your relationship with food. as much as i wish i could give you an easy answer for how to not binge after a large dinner or eating  cookies or how to not worry about everything that's in what you're eating, i know it's not that simple and easy.  it took me YEARS to get to where i am with food, and what eventually helped me to fully heal were letting go of the ideas that eating less was better, that different foods were “good” and “bad”, that calories were meant to be “burned off”, that gaining weight was a bad thing, etc., and trusting and committing to the process of honoring my body and giving myself *UNCONDITIONAL* permission to eat (i promise the time it takes is worth it).
——
the ability to not binge after eating multiple desserts or to go into a big meal and not even think about how many calories you may be eating isn't something that happens overnight, and real change takes time. while i don't have any quick fixes for you, i hope you remember what this time of year is really about, think about the things you hope to look back fondly on, know that it's okay to do what you need to do to protect your own peace, celebrate every small step and win you have, and give yourself the grace and compassion you deserve.
——
chicken and waffles from @sohochickenandwhiskey, one of my all time fave spots in cle!!

Doc ID: 14331, distribution: 0.6325854559358048 ; Therapy .. // eating disorder remission // part one  So this session I thought I would reflect on my eating disorder and how much better it is. I wanted to share this with T to kind of fix it in place, and to show her how far I have come. I talked away for a long time. Several months ago, we spent quite a few weeks wrestling with the idea of me eating cake. It was something I had a huge block about and that was still causing me a lot of eating disorder thoughts. Eventually we got me to a place where I felt like I was able to eat cake, which subsequently had lots of knock on effects, such as being able to eat sweet things at home, less cravings and obsessing, less chewing and spitting etc. It felt like the final big hurdle left in recovery had now been cleared.  I said how with my eating disorder, every eating episode became separate and disconnected from every other. So I couldn't connect that what I ate or didn't eat at one meal or on one day would have a knock on effect on the next meal or next day. Eating, appetite and fuelling my body didn't “reset” every night. Eating a snack in the moment just became a very black or white choice, do I want to put these calories in my body? I couldn't connect it up to how it was just a part of the whole day of eating. But gradually that's something I've learnt to be able to do. To think about nourishing myself as a positive thing and how all these different meals and snacks combine to keep me well fuelled and healthy both mentally and physically. I said how I didn't want to say I was “recovered” because that seemed overconfident and like I was never going to stumble again. I mentioned that maybe it would be more accurate to say it was in remission. T didn't seem to have come across that concept with regard to eating disorders before. She came back to it and said that was an interesting idea. I wish now I'd asked her a bit more about this, and about what she thought.  I said that although everything was pretty good right now, I could think of situations that might knock me pretty hard. For example, if I got a stomach bug and lost some weight, I feel like I would find that really triggering and I think I could easily fall into that downward spiral. I also said that I knew that in lockdown, life was about as unchallenging as it gets, foodwise. I was eating all my meals at home, eating exactly what I chose, no meals out, no coffee shops with cake to negotiate and so on. I've got to know my body pretty well over the last couple of years, and how it responds and what it needs in various situations and activity levels, and I feel like I am able to make healthy choices for myself now. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 14668, distribution: 0.6170425886880868 ; Therapy .. // can anyone relate?  T said we should maybe try and focus more on how I feel in my body, in terms of energy, warmth etc, and less on weight and bmi. She can say this because I'm in a stable place with a healthy weight, so it's about learning I can trust my body and my perceptions of it. This bought up something I'd been thinking about those week, about my internalised sense of the size of my body. I thought everybody had this idea of their size, of how much space they take up. T thought it was interesting that I used the words “how much space I take up”. I said it referred to an internal frame of reference, as if looking at the body from inside it, rather than being outside it and looking at how big it is is compared to external things. I said that my sense of how much space I take up is that it's much bigger than it really is, and I wondered how to change that. T struggled to answer because she couldn't really relate to the idea of how much space we take up. In my head, I'm still about  lbs heavier than I really am. When I think about it, I can be rational and know I'm not, but my first instinct is still that I'm that size. (I haven't been that size for over  years) We didn't come to a solution, we just left it there. Having thought about it since, I might use this example for T next week: If you go to the fairground and walk past one of those silly mirrors that distorts you to make you taller, most people would know that their reflection is distorted. That's not because you have a logical conversation with yourself where you think oh I know I'm not  foot tall so that must be a distortion. It's because you have an image in your head of how you look, and so instantaneously you can know that reflection is not representative of how much vertical space you really take up. My struggle is that if the mirror distorted widthwards, I would not recognise it was distorted. The image of myself in my head is so out of whack that whenever I see my reflection, I do a double take because I am surprised at what I see. I look at women I pass in the street and I think, is that what I look like? Am I bigger than that? Smaller than that? Can anyone relate to this? 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 16702, distribution: 0.5277017816642752 ; Therapy .. // part  // weight going down; frustration going up  My therapist said she was trying a different approach this week and trying to help the adult-me get on board with making the decisions, rather than her telling me what to do. She asked me how I was finding it. I was looking down because I was feeling fed up that she wasn't really getting me, and I muttered  “It's annoying!” I don't think T expected that because she sounded a bit taken aback and gave a little laugh and said “oh… right, ok”. I smiled too. It actually was a moment of connection in amongst all the disconnect. She said “How can I be helpful to you? What do you need from me? I want to support the adult part of you to make decisions.” I got frustrated and said “Yes but it doesn't have to be one extreme or the other!” while gesturing extremes with my hands. I understand that T taking the adult role and telling me what to do, while it has a place at times, is only really a stepping stone to enabling me to look after myself more fully. But at the same time when she completely steps back and refuses to get drawn into that adult role, it feels like she has abandoned me. I sat in silence for quite a long time. Lots was happening in my head. I was feeling frustrated about how things were going. I was wondering why she hadn't asked about my weight, when we have spent so many sessions talking about it and even last session she spent some time hammering me on eating.  I managed to use the silence quite constructively. I was weighing up in my head whether to just abandon the weight conversation and talk about something else, or whether that would leave things feeling really difficult over my upcoming holiday. I thought to myself, What will be the hardest thing to manage myself next week when I don't have a session? and the answer came back in my mind that it would be T not knowing my weight and the places my brain/eating disorder might run off to with that. Eventually I spoke, although I avoided eye contact. “Uh…. it bothers me that you still don't know what I weigh. That I said I was worried about telling you it but now you don't seem to care whether I tell you it or not! It's hard for me to tell you it each week and I need to feel like it's non-negotiable, because that's sometimes the only way I can make myself write it. So it wasn't that I didn't want to tell you it this week, I was just scared of what you would think.” T said that she could pretty much figure out what my weight is from the other things I said about it. She made a guess and I kind of nodded slowly, till she said “lower?” I nodded and she guessed again, correctly this time. I said I didn't mean it to be that low, I knew I'd missed some meals but I'd also not missed a lot.  “I was honest when I answered your texts about eating. And it did help, you texting me, but then I felt like a terrible person because I implied everything was ok in the texts and then I went and lost a load of weight….. Here I am, supposed to be in recovery and instead I am making all these choices that aren't in line with that. I'm a terrible person.” T reminded me that recovery is never a straight line and that it's normal to have some relapses.  She was very determined not to get all parental on me, and I guess I felt uncomfortable with the changed dynamic and just kept trying to prod her back into it. She offered to text me again through the next fortnight to ask how eating was going, but I didn't feel like I deserved anymore support so I said no.  Despite all that, we ended the session on a good note. It wasn't a rupture. Just an uncomfortable session with things to think about. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 16841, distribution: 0.6235790357381454 ; Therapy .. // weight again  We jumped around topics a lot in this therapy session, but that felt ok. We touched on lots of things, but some didn't need more than a touch this week. Just to be brought into the room and left to consider. The first topic we talked about was my weight. I was convinced I'd gained about lbs. As soon as I change my routine or miss a weigh in, I become certain I'm getting bigger and bigger. The new jeans didn't help because they felt tight while I was wearing them in, and my brain immediately equates that to “I'm so fat”.  “I didn't get to the gym to weigh myself on Sunday evening to weigh myself because we were away for the weekend. That's why I didn't text you it. But I'm sure it's gone up. I feel huge.” “Ok… shall we talk about this now?” “I don't think there's much to say. I feel horrible.” T asks about how my clothes feel. She's trying to help me be more in touch with the size of my body without being reliant on a number on the scale. We talked about eating and whether what I call “ok” is the same as what T would call ok. “Uhh yep I think you would think it's ok. I'm eating three meals, just struggling with the snacks. I often don't feel good physically though. I know I'm not eating enough and I would be better with snacks, but my head won't let me eat them.” “Do you feel like your blood sugar is low?” “Yeah sometimes. And I go in the kitchen and look at the food… but now I'm not eating peanut butter I don't have anything else safe to snack on.” “What's helped in the past?….[pause]…. Shall I have a go at answering that for you? I think what's helped is knowing that you'll feel better if you eat more.” I nod. T suggests some things that I have eaten for snacks in the past. My brain makes excuses for all of them. A milky hot chocolate sounds the least impossible. I think because it was T who first got me into drinking that and it feels kind of nurturing to think about having one because T wants me to have one. If that makes sense. We have had versions of this whole weight conversation endless times in past therapy sessions. It only lasts - minutes but it can often be enough of a nudge to keep me on track. And it's good to check in about it each week.  In order to prevent us getting locked in an endless circular debate about eating, T says “Soo…shall we park this for now?”. I know it, I know everything she is saying, it's good to hear it again and I just need to work myself up to taking some action. So I nod, yes let's move on. I'm grateful to her for managing the session time and not insisting we thrash it out to the end. We have been in that situation before, when I needed it, but I am so much better than I was and so much more steady with my intake. I have to remember that when my intake drops below a certain level, other eating disorder behaviours rush in. Those pathways are in my brain and I'm vulnerable to falling back into them. I just never believe that my intake is that low until I start doing those other things *eyeroll* *facepalm* 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 15926, distribution: 0.24610996645466257 ; Motivation to keep eating  One of the things that makes it harder for me to maintain an adequate intake in these times is that one of my big motivations for recovery has always been to have enough energy to go out to groups and to socialise. I'm naturally an introvert and very happy in my own company, so while I do enjoy going out and about and seeing friends, it does take that energy to do that. One of my lowest points when I was unwell and restricting badly was getting H to take the three girls out of the house (they were about ,  and ), and I just couldn't wait for them all to go away so I could just lie on my bed and not have to interact with anyone.  I feel a lot of shame about some of the things I wanted then, even though I know it was because I was unwell. It all motivates me to stay in recovery now, because I never want to get to that low place again. I want to have the energy to meet people, and take the baby to groups and chat with people, and to be present when I'm out with friends instead of being zoned out or completely preoccupied with food. But now with this lockdown, I can't go out and socialise with anyone. I don't need energy to be present with my friends for a couple of hours over lunch, or to go to a new baby group and make conversation with people I don't know. Of course the family are still around and we are still having Zoom conversations and I am still FaceTiming with individual friends, but all that seems to take much less extrovert energy when done from the comfort of my own home. (It still take some though!) Anyway, all that is to say that there's a bit of my brain saying “ah now, you don't really need to eat so much these days, it doesn't matter if you miss bits here and there because you don't need all that energy, you don't need to push yourself to be present with people outside your family, you can just exist in this bubble”. I totally know it's the eating disorder and I need to push back against it. It's just hard when it's been one of my core motivations to keep my intake up and now it's been knocked out from under me. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 15437, distribution: 1.0 ; Therapy .. // controversial  T asked “Can I say something a bit controversial?” What sort of a question is that?? As I said to T, “How do I know whether it's ok for you to say it? Because I won't know if it is until you've said it, and then if it's not ok it'll be too late!” She said that was very true. We went back and forth a bit and eventually I said “ok, say it then.” T said “So… you know that list you showed me last week about all the steps in recovery? And being able to buy yourself a snack while you're out is just about the last thing left on it… I'm wondering if you might be thinking - subconsciously, I mean - if you don't want to be able to eat cake because that would mean you would have to finish therapy.” I looked at T a bit weirdly. That honestly has not crossed my mind. If I can go out and treat myself to cake, there are still other bits and pieces of eating disorder behaviours I could choose to work on (oh gosh she knows some of the things I do, I know I have told her them) or there is other relationship stuff we could work on. I don't feel at all like being able to eat cake would automatically mean Bingo! I was done!  But of course the stupid thing about things like this when a therapist says “oh it's not your conscious mind” is that you can't win that argument. If you disagree, they just say that's because you're not aware of it.  I said to T that I didn't think that was true at all and it hadn't crossed my mind, and true to form she said something very similar to what I just wrote. I felt like the more I argued with her, the more she might think it was indeed true, so I just kind of shrugged and gave her a weak smile. I told her I still felt like I had stuff to work on in therapy if I chose to. And I didn't say this, but I am gradually more reconciled to the idea of finishing therapy at some point. It doesn't freak me out like it used to. I am ready to have a good end at some point. I don't want a therapy that is forced to end through circumstance, I want to be in control of the ending and it to be by our mutual choice. So that means we have to make that choice at some point. 
------------------------------------------------------------
Doc ID: 16367, distribution: 0.6231714310215456 ; Therapy .. // running and weighing  We got to just over halfway through the session and T reminded me that we'd agreed that we would stop talking about Christmas and talk about the other things I had to talk about.  I told her I'd signed up on impulse for a half marathon, and that I hope that I could train for it in a healthy way. We talked about what it might look like if it wasn't a healthy way. I said not taking rest days, running more than my training plan. She said what about if you start losing weight? You know you'll need to eat more to fuel more running. I said eating more was… difficult. We had a bit of a back and forth about that. I said I was very motivated to be able to train well and run fast and that I did think I would be able to eat adequately to do that.  T said I would need to keep an eye on my weight and I said uh actually, I want to stop weighing myself. Because I've done it every week for a year now and it's starting to feel more unhelpful than helpful. It just keeps me fixated on the number and I can't stop my urges to make it go down, no matter what it is.   I said that last year my weight had ranged over  lbs and I knew what that felt like and I would recognise if it moved outside that. T said “I think you are a good weight at the moment”, which was and is hard to hear. It definitely makes me aware of a part of me that still wants people to be concerned about me because I am “too thin”. There is a big part of me that is really really proud of myself for getting rid of a load of eating disorder behaviours, eating regularly, exercising in a healthy way and engaging in adult life as an adult. Life is so much better with all these things in place. But there's still that little part that wants to be looked after and taken care of and doesn't like to hear “hey you're doing really well, we don't need to worry about that anymore”. Anyway, that is my self awareness which I can use to understand why I feel certain ways while also knowing that I don't need to act on it. T was understanding of my wish not to weigh myself so often, and she said that towards the end of last year she thought I had got a bit hyperfocused on the numbers again, so maybe it would be a good idea to step away from them. I do imagine I'll still weigh myself, but maybe only once a month or so, and just to see if it's still in the range rather than getting caught up in the exact numbers. We finished off by talking a bit about goals for the year. T suggested a goal that I would know what I was feeling in my body and how that related to my emotions. I'm a bit unsure what exactly she means but I'm happy to go with it. Then we got on to talking about finishing therapy, which I wrote about in a previous post, and that was the end of the session.
